Yuhei Takashima, a former Japanese school principal, has been charged with paying for sex with over 12,000 women, including some underage girls, in the Philippines. The alleged incidents occurred between 1988 and 2014, with some victims being as young as 13 or 14 years old. Police officers seized 147,600 photos taken by Takashima, which included explicit images of him engaging in sex acts with multiple women. Takashima faces criminal charges after being arrested in Manila, where he allegedly bought sex from prostitutes ranging in age from 14 to 70.

Gareth Bale's name appears on the back of a new Chelsea kit, which was allegedly sold through a Brazilian online retailer. The kit features the sponsor Yokohama, but does not include the Adidas logo. Three other Chelsea kits were released, each featuring the club's current sponsor. Fans who wish to buy the kit without Bale's name on the back may prefer to opt for a different design. Meanwhile, Didier Drogba's Chelsea jersey is available for purchase, although his future remains uncertain due to an expired contract.

Clarence Taylor, 44, faked his own kidnapping in Akron, Ohio, by duct-taping his mouth and tying himself to a tree in a bizarre incident. His 45-year-old girlfriend reported him missing on November 1, only to be contacted by a friend who led police to him tied to a tree with zip ties. The friend allegedly stole $2,500 from Taylor before abducting him and taking him away in a van. Taylor claims he was left tied to the tree for several days without showing signs of dehydration or injury. Police charged Taylor with a first-degree misdemeanor charge of falsification due to the circumstances surrounding the incident.

A new satirical video from the Make It Fair Project promotes gender equality in Hollywood, featuring actresses highlighting the disparity between men and women in various industries. The video, starring Rita Wilson, showcases statistics showing that men hold 70-95% of key positions in Hollywood, such as directing and writing, and pay significantly more than women. The actresses, including Meryl Streep's daughter Mamie Gummer, sing a tongue-in-cheek song criticizing the status quo. The video aims to raise awareness about the issue and encourage change through social media using the hashtag #MakeItFair.

Researchers suggest that warmer climates around 1.4 million years ago allowed early humans to settle in Western Europe, enabling them to spread across the continent. This occurred when temperatures rose above 13°C (55°F), increasing humidity and making it possible for hominins to hunt and gather food using tools like stone hand axes. The warm climate also supported the growth of the 'Nutcracker Man' species, which had distinctive powerful jaws and large teeth. As the climate continued to warm, the hominin population expanded further, eventually spreading across Europe.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL running back, is suspected of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward, a 37-year-old inmate serving a life sentence for first-degree murder in Central California prison. Phillips, who was previously convicted of choking his girlfriend and driving into three teenagers, is believed to have killed Soward while sharing a cell. The incident occurred at Kern Valley State Prison, where Phillips is serving a 31-year sentence. A second inmate is also suspected of killing Soward, although their relationship to Phillips is unknown. Both incidents are under investigation by prison officials and law enforcement agencies.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers' FA Cup semi-final defeat to Aston Villa has sparked concerns about the team's chances of achieving their ambitious goal of becoming Champions League regulars. Despite having a talented squad, Rodgers' inability to find consistency and form has raised questions about whether he can lead the team to success. The loss has also highlighted the need for significant changes, particularly in terms of player transfers and personnel management. Rodgers has vowed to learn from his mistakes and improve, but the pressure remains high, especially with the departure of several key players, including Raheem Sterling and Daniel Sturridge. With the FA Cup semi-final defeat, Liverpool's hopes of progressing to the final seem uncertain, and the team's future under Rodgers is far from certain.

Google Maps combines with Pac-Man game for an impish April Fools' Day prank. Users can play a Pac-Man game within Google Maps by simply clicking on the icon. The game allows users to navigate through a virtual course, similar to a traditional Pac-Man challenge. The prank was rolled out as part of Google's efforts to create a unique experience for April Fools' Day.

Rangers manager Stuart McCall has reassured fans that the removal of the club from the AIM stock exchange will not affect his team's promotion push. The club was previously removed from the AIM due to chairman-in-waiting Dave King failing to find a new nominated advisor, but interim chairman Paul Murray attributed the decision to the previous board. McCall has stated that he doesn't expect the situation to negatively impact his team, despite the potential financial implications. Rangers welcomed newly-crowned Scottish Championship winners Hearts to Ibrox on Sunday, where they will give the Hearts players a guard of honour. McCall expressed confidence in his team's ability to overcome the setback and secure promotion.

A US-based organization, Vox Populi, is attempting to use the ".sucks" domain name to target celebrities and companies for financial gain. They claim this is a "coercive scheme" and threaten to open sites to the general public unless they pay a fee. Celebrities such as Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have already had their names removed from these domains, while others like Visa and Bank of America have also been targeted. Vox Populi claims that the threat of opening these sites to the public is necessary to protect their reputation.

Manchester United have been linked with signing Edinson Cavani despite his disappointing 2-0 loss to Barcelona in the Champions League. Cavani's performance was described as "sterile" and he failed to impress, while Radamel Falcao's loan spell at Manchester United has left the club wary of signing him due to his struggles. Cavani's domestic form has also been underwhelming, scoring just 6 goals in 32 appearances in Ligue 1. Despite this, Cavani remains committed to staying at Paris Saint-Germain until the end of his contract. With Barcelona looking unstoppable, there are concerns that they may be able to sign Cavani, who has already signed with the club.

Leicester City appear to be safe from relegation with a predicted total of 26 points, thanks to their strong home record and favorable fixture schedule. Sunderland, meanwhile, are in a tight spot with 15 points, while Burnley, Everton, Aston Villa, and Steve Bruce's Hull are fighting to avoid the drop. Arsenal, however, have a relatively easy run-in, with five home games ahead of them, while QPR and Sunderland are among the teams with the most games left to play. With their goal difference being significantly lower than some other teams, QPR may struggle to avoid relegation, while Sunderland's survival bid relies heavily on their ability to secure home victories.

Karim Benzema showcased his vocal talents by rapping along to Tupac's "All Eyez on Me" while driving his Bugatti Veyron. He sang the song with confidence, stating he can win the Ballon d'Or award despite being part of Real Madrid's struggles. Benzema also expressed his determination to continue performing well for both club and country. His teammates, Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi, have already secured major awards, leaving Benzema to focus on his own goals. Benzema believes he can surpass them in the near future.

Pope Francis, 78, has been advised by doctors to cut down on his pasta intake due to concerns over his considerable weight gain since taking office. The Vatican has also urged him to increase his physical activity, such as taking daily walks, to alleviate his sciatica. Doctors cited his sedentary lifestyle and recent comments suggesting he may not live beyond his current term as a contributing factors. Despite this, Pope Francis has dismissed the advice, jokingly referring to himself as "the undisciplined one."

Google has released an updated version of its Android software that allows users to unlock their smartphones using their voice instead of a password. The "trusted voice" feature uses the user's voice to unlock their device, which can be accessed through the Google app's settings. This feature is available on certain Android devices, such as those running Android 4.4 KitKat or later. Users must first enable the feature by tapping the "Smart Lock" option, followed by taking a photo of themselves with the device's front-facing camera. The feature is considered secure, but not as secure as traditional locks, and requires a small margin of error to ensure correct identification.

A lawyer for Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve deputy, has released documents showing that Bates attended multiple training sessions, including a Taser training class and three firearms training classes, between 2009 and 2014. These documents contradict previous reports that suggested Bates was unqualified to be a reserve deputy due to low firearm qualification scores. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office has denied these allegations, stating that Bates' training was sufficient to meet the requirements. A lawyer for the victim's family claims that Bates was given preferential treatment due to his financial contributions to the agency and friendship with the sheriff.

A leading headteacher at Sherborne Preparatory School in Dorset claims that parents have become overly involved in their children's education, putting them at risk of developing unhealthy relationships with teachers. This trend stems from parents bombarding them with information and pressure to excel academically. The situation has led to an increase in abuse towards teachers, with many experiencing verbal harassment, threats, and online intimidation. Parents must learn to trust schools and teachers rather than trying to control every aspect of their child's life.

A deal between six world powers aimed at thwarting Iran's nuclear ambitions has been met with criticism from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who argues that it does not effectively roll back Iran's nuclear program. The deal, which includes limits on Iran's enrichment and inspections, was endorsed by President Barack Obama but opposed by many Republicans, who see it as giving Iran too much flexibility. Netanyahu claims that the deal would allow Iran to continue building a nuclear bomb, while others argue that it would prevent Iran from gaining significant advantages. The US government has stated that the deal would extend the breakout time period for Iran to build a nuclear bomb, allowing for faster detection and response.

Catalans Dragons winger Vincent Duport has been ruled out for the rest of the season due to a shoulder injury sustained during their 33-22 loss to Hull FC. He underwent surgery as a result of the injury. This setback comes just weeks after he returned from a previous injury. The French international's absence will be felt by the team, but his coach believes he will recover quickly. With the upcoming match against Wigan scheduled, the Dragons will look to bounce back from this setback.

A 36-year-old Indiana woman named Samantha Fleming went missing with her 3-month-old newborn daughter Serenity in April. Police discovered her body in a home in Gary, Indiana, 180 miles away from her original location, where a woman claiming to be from Child Protective Services told her she needed to attend a court hearing. The woman allegedly took the baby to a nursery and had planned to care for it, but the baby was later found dead in a home in Gary. The woman, who is now identified as a person of interest, was questioned by police and is believed to be familiar with Fleming.

A 20,000-year-old pyramid has been discovered in West Java, Indonesia, challenging the notion that the world's oldest pyramid is located in Egypt. This ancient structure, believed to be built between 9,000 and 20,000 years ago, is thought to be a temple rather than a pyramid due to its unique design and construction method. The discovery sheds new light on the development of human civilization, suggesting that ancient cultures were capable of constructing monumental architecture thousands of years before the Egyptians. The site, marked as "Gunung Padang", features terraces and retaining walls, indicating a sophisticated engineering feat.

A 29-year-old man was stabbed by a 27-year-old man outside a Melbourne nightclub on Easter long weekend. The incident occurred when the 27-year-old man returned to the club after being ejected and attacked the 29-year-old bouncer from behind. A separate incident also occurred earlier in the day involving a 24-year-old man who was stabbed in a different location. Footage shows the shocking moments leading up to the attacks, which were caught on camera. The victims were treated for minor injuries and are receiving medical attention.

Keith Curle, Carlisle United manager, criticized his team's performance after a 3-1 loss to Accrington Stanley, calling some players "players who don't deserve to be professionals." The Cumbrians are struggling in League Two, having lost five games in their last five matches. Curle expressed frustration about the lack of effort from certain players, stating that they need to show more character and accountability. A potential open forum for fans will be held to discuss their concerns.

Victoria's Secret's new campaign features Candice Swanepoel, Elsa Hosk, and Jasmine Tookes showcasing their Dream Angels lingerie range. The campaign promotes the brand's new line, featuring white bras, push-up bras, and lace-trimmed tops. Candice Swanepoel appears in the campaign alongside Elsa Hosk and Jasmine Tookes, wearing various outfits and accessories. The campaign aims to showcase the brand's new lingerie range, which includes items such as DKNY Intimates lace bras and Ciao Bella bras.

A Ukrainian-born singer named Kristina Karo is suing Hollywood actress Mila Kunis for $5,000, claiming that she stole her pet chicken, "Doggie", 25 years ago while they were classmates in Ukraine. Karo alleges that Kunis confessed to stealing the chicken and offered her a new one, forcing her to return home. The incident occurred when Karo was just seven years old, and it allegedly traumatized her, leading her to seek therapy. Karo claims that moving to Los Angeles, where she currently resides, has brought back painful memories of the incident.

Richard Howarth, a 35-year-old medical recruitment consultant, claims he develops an intense physical reaction every time he sees Nigel Farage, the leader of Ukip, on TV. This reaction causes him to break out in a sweat and become anxious, leading him to switch the channel or take medication to manage his symptoms. According to his wife, Catherine, the reactions are so severe that they make him physically ill. A psychologist attributes the phenomenon to a phobia, stating that people can develop irrational fears based on their opposition to someone's views.

Rahul Kumar, a 17-year-old boy, jumped into a lions' enclosure at a zoo in Ahmedabad, thinking he'd have an advantage against the predators. He shouted "Today I kill a lion!" as he ran towards the animals, despite being intoxicated. Luckily, he fell into a moat and was caught by zoo security staff who rescued him before he reached the lions. The incident highlights the dangers of intoxication and the importance of animal safety measures.

A typical Easter egg contains nearly 7 teaspoons of sugar, exceeding the recommended daily intake of 50g. Consuming these sweets can lead to insulin resistance, a precursor to type 2 diabetes, and contribute to obesity, tooth decay, and nutrient deficiencies. Eating too much sugar can cause significant negative impacts on overall health, particularly in children. Experts warn that indulging in certain types of Easter treats, such as Kit Kat Chunky and Flakes, can trigger insulin resistance and negatively affect the nation's health. Regular consumption of these sweets can lead to increased risk of developing conditions like type 2 diabetes and obesity.

The Havasupai tribe, a small Indian nation in Arizona, USA, lives in the remote village of Supai, nestled at the bottom of Havasu Canyon in the Grand Canyon National Park. With a population of around 600 people, the tribe relies heavily on tourism to support itself, generating income from sales of goods and services such as food, crafts, and lodging. The village is accessible only by foot, helicopter, or mule, offering breathtaking views of the stunning natural wonder below. The tribe's connection to the land is deeply rooted in their spiritual beliefs, and they consider themselves guardians of the sacred site.

A new malaria vaccine called RTS,S has been developed after 30 years of research, with the goal of preventing millions of cases worldwide. The vaccine, licensed by the European Medicines Agency, has shown promising results in reducing clinical cases of malaria among toddlers and babies in sub-Saharan Africa. According to the World Health Organization, the vaccine could prevent around 1,363 cases of malaria for every 1,000 children vaccinated annually. This could translate to millions of lives saved globally, particularly in regions where malaria is prevalent. The vaccine is expected to be approved by October, marking a significant milestone in the fight against the disease.

Chilean pickpockets have become the most effective thieves operating in central London, targeting wealthy tourists in busy shopping areas like Oxford Street. These gangs, estimated to be made up of up to six members, use intelligence-led tactics to evade detection and steal large amounts of cash and valuables. The Metropolitan Police have reported a significant decrease in pickpocket crimes in recent years, thanks to increased surveillance and cooperation between agencies. The majority of arrested pickpockets are from Romania, Bulgaria, and other countries, while Chilean nationals make up a smaller percentage.

A new, sleeker version of the traditional electricity pylon has been unveiled in the UK, marking a significant milestone in the country's efforts to reduce its reliance on outdated technology. This innovative design features a lower profile and reduced weight, making it easier to install and maintain. The new T-pylon, part of a larger training program, aims to improve efficiency and safety while reducing environmental impact. As part of a broader effort to modernize the grid, National Grid plans to deploy these new pylons alongside existing lattice structures, replacing some of the older units.

Holly Nicole Solomon, a 31-year-old woman from Arizona, pleaded guilty to aggravated assault after hitting her husband Daniel with their SUV in a parking lot dispute over his non-voting status in the 2012 presidential election. Solomon claimed she wanted to scare her husband, but accidentally accelerated instead of braking, causing him serious injuries. Her husband Daniel Solomon suffered a shattered pelvis and a torn artery, and was hospitalized in critical condition. Solomon faces up to 15 years in prison if convicted of aggravated assault. She pleaded guilty to the crime and agreed to a plea deal, which includes serving three and a half years in prison.

Student Drew Hollinshead, 21, stopped his car to help an elderly woman who collapsed on the pavement while he was parked in a disabled bay. A traffic warden issued him a £70 parking ticket despite seeing him assist the woman for just 30-45 seconds. Hollinshead initially tore up the ticket and threw it away but later retrieved it, saying "it's not the cost, it's the principle." He has since taken to social media to express his frustration, stating that the situation was "ridiculous" and that the council does not care if the fine is upheld.

Chinese builders in Pingjiang County, Hunan province, are constructing a precarious walkway for tourists to hike along a mountainous region. The walkway is being built using rickety wooden planks and is supported by flimsy-looking wooden scaffolding poles. The construction process involves hauling heavy loads of concrete and wood across the narrow walkway, which is precariously perched thousands of feet above the ground. Officials aim to attract tourists to the area, which already draws thousands of visitors to its natural beauty.

Pennine Acute Hospitals NHS Trust, a healthcare provider in Greater Manchester, UK, has faced criticism for its maternity services after a series of high-profile deaths involving babies and mothers over a period of eight months. An independent investigation revealed significant failings in clinical leadership, risk management, and patient care, resulting in the deaths of ten individuals. The investigation found that national guidelines for treating obese mothers were not followed, contributing to the tragic events. The report highlighted concerns about inadequate staffing levels and poor communication among medical staff, leading to delayed interventions and ultimately, the loss of life.

A new governing board has been established in Ferguson, Missouri, replacing the previous six-member City Council. Two African-American candidates, Ella Jones and Wesley Bell, won their respective seats, making the council 50% black. The election was marked by high voter turnout, with over 20,000 people casting their ballots, mostly in response to the recent death of Michael Brown, whose killing sparked widespread protests and calls for change. The new council members aim to address issues related to policing and economic development, with Fletcher promising to focus on community policing and Fletcher's opponent wanting to increase revenue through fines and traffic tickets.

Australian cricketer Aaron Finch underwent surgery on his left hamstring after suffering a high-grade injury during the Indian Premier League. He was diagnosed with the injury while playing for the Mumbai Indians and required scans to confirm the extent of the damage. Finch will face a lengthy recovery period as he seeks to return to full fitness. The 28-year-old batsman was initially expected to miss several months but will instead undergo rehabilitation for up to 12 weeks. Finch's absence from international cricket means he won't participate in the upcoming World Cup or England's Ashes tour.

AP McCoy secured his second win of the Aintree meeting with a decisive performance on Cause of Causes, a gelding owned by his boss JP McManus. Gordon Elliott trains the gelding, which won the Melling Chase, beating a strong field led by Don Cossack. McCoy rode the impressive Don Cossack to victory, marking his second win of the meeting. The win cements Elliott's position as a leading trainer, having enjoyed a successful meeting so far.

Vince Cable, a closet Labour politician who previously served as a councillor, has expressed his desire to work with the Conservatives again despite being described as the "bogeyman" in the Coalition Cabinet. He claims to have realized that being business-like with the Tories is possible and envisions a scenario where he would stomach working with them if necessary. Cable has been critical of his own party leader Ed Miliband, describing him as "disappointed" and accusing him of making "poor judgment." However, he remains loyal to the Conservatives and has stated that he would consider replacing George Osborne as Chancellor if the situation requires it. Cable has vowed to remain in government, citing his passion for the economy and his experience in various government roles.

A survey of 2000 British workers found that the average worker attends 6,239 meetings throughout their careers, with 60% finding most meetings "pretty pointless". Many workers also confess to zoning out or sleeping during meetings, citing boredom and lack of relevance as reasons. A significant proportion of workers admit to sneaking off-site meetings to avoid attending, suggesting that internal meetings may be unnecessary. The survey highlights the importance of taking breaks and prioritizing productivity, with technology allowing for more efficient communication and reducing the need for lengthy meetings.

A math problem was created for 14-year-old students in the Singapore and Asian Schools Math Olympiad (SASMO) to solve. The question, "When is Cheryl's birthday?" involved 25 questions, where each question led to a different solution. Cheryl gave Albert and Bernard a list of 10 possible birthdays, and Albert and Bernard tried to figure out the correct answer based on the clues provided. After working through the clues, Albert finally determined that Cheryl's birthday was July 16.

A federal prosecutor accused Army Major John and his wife Carolyn Jackson of abusing their three young foster children over several years, leaving them with physical injuries and health problems. The couple's first child abuse trial resulted in a mistrial due to a minor detail being mentioned in court, but the second trial is ongoing. The Jacksons have three biological children and three adopted children, and authorities say they used various forms of discipline, including withholding food and water, to punish their foster children. Carolyn Jackson has defended her actions, saying she acted in good faith as a parent, while attorneys argue that her behavior rose to the level of abuse.

Real Madrid is set to face Atletico Madrid in the Champions League quarter-finals due to Karim Benzema's absence. The French striker is out with a knee injury, while Gareth Bale and Luka Modric are also expected to miss the match. Carlo Ancelotti has hinted that Benzema may return for the second leg, despite initial doubts about his availability. Meanwhile, Real Madrid's 3-1 win over Malaga has raised questions about the team's chances of advancing to the semi-finals. The match is scheduled for Wednesday, with both teams looking to secure a spot in the knockout stages.

A group of thieves, possibly linked to the Hatton Garden raid, carried out a similarly audacious burglary in Berlin in January 2013, targeting 294 security vaults and stealing valuable items worth around £8.3 million. This incident bears striking similarities to the £60m heist in London, which occurred over the same Easter weekend. The thieves used heavy-duty drills to breach reinforced walls and tunnels to gain access to the vaults, disguising themselves as construction workers. The investigation suggests that the Berlin heist may have been aided by an insider, and police are still investigating whether anyone was involved.

A young child's reaction to witnessing the tragic scene of Mufasa's murder in Disney's The Lion King has been captured on camera by her father, Barles Charkley. The video shows the toddler's distressing moment when she watches the scene unfold, prompting her to react with a mix of sadness and fear. The clip, shot by Charkley, has garnered millions of views online. The scene is widely regarded as one of Disney's most haunting spectacles, featuring the iconic character Simba's father being brutally killed by his treacherous brother Scar.

A couple in their 40s were denied a £250,000 mortgage application by HSBC due to the bank's age policy, which deemed the husband too old to qualify for an interest-only loan. The couple, who did not want to be named, claimed they were victims of age discrimination. An investigation by the Financial Ombudsman Service found that HSBC had relied on untested assumptions about age in making the decision. The bank was ordered to pay £500 to the couple for distress and inconvenience caused.

A Texas veterinarian, Kristen Lindsey, was fired from her job after posting a photo of a cat she shot with an arrow on Facebook, sparking outrage among animal lovers. The cat, which was later identified as a feral tomcat, was actually the pet of an elderly couple who called the clinic to complain about the incident. Lindsey claimed she didn't shoot the cat, but the clinic and animal control investigated and ultimately decided to fire her due to the severity of the situation. A $7,500 reward is being offered by cat advocacy group Alley Cat Allies for evidence leading to Lindsey's conviction.

A renowned facial surgeon, Professor Ninian Peckitt, has been accused of repeatedly punching a patient in the face during a closed reduction procedure to correct a fracture caused by an industrial accident. The patient, referred to as 'Patient A', suffered extensive injuries to the right side of their face. Peckitt allegedly performed the procedure without proper training or supervision, despite claiming it was done "digitally" to achieve the best possible result. The incident occurred while Peckitt worked as an honorary locum consultant at Ipswich Hospital in February 2012.

Actor Ben Powers, best known for his role as Thelma's husband Keith on the long-running sitcom "Good Times," has passed away at the age of 64 after a private battle with illness. He was a talented artist before pursuing a career in acting, studying painting and sketching at the Rhode Island School of Design. Powers also appeared in various TV shows and films, including "Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer" and "Cheech & Chong's Next Movie." A close friend of actress Bern Nadette Stanis, who played Thelma, expressed her condolences on social media.

Derby drew 1-1 with Brentford in a thrilling match at the iPro Stadium. Alex Pritchard scored a stunning 21st-minute goal for Brentford, only to be matched by Darren Bent's late equalizer in stoppage time. The Bees dominated the first half, but Derby fought back with goals from Bent and Pritchard, while also having several other chances denied. In the end, Bent's late winner sealed a hard-fought 1-1 draw for Derby.

A gang of armed robbers used pink umbrellas to disguise themselves during a two-month crime spree targeting 13 shops in the West Midlands, stealing £145,000 worth of cigarettes and cars valued at £30,000. The gang, led by Marcus Morgan, used hammers, knives, and screwdrivers to threaten shop workers, causing physical altercations, and punched one employee in the face. The group was eventually caught after a raid on an Asda supermarket, where they were armed with hammers and a gun, and later searched their homes, revealing evidence linking them to the other robberies. The gang members were arrested and convicted of multiple counts of conspiracy to rob, with some receiving lengthy prison sentences ranging from six months to eight years.

Italian Alex Bellini, a 36-year-old explorer, plans to spend a year living inside a 10ft-wide ball-shaped capsule on top of an iceberg in Greenland, aiming to raise awareness about global warming and climate change through his project "Adrift". The capsule, designed to withstand extreme temperatures and potential iceberg flips, will allow him to observe the melting process up close. Seeking funding, Bellini aims to complete his project in November 2016, which includes living inside the capsule for 12 months. His goal is to study the effects of climate change on icebergs and their impact on sea levels.

A photograph circulated on social media site SnapChat appears to show disgraced Geelong College principal Andrew Barr watching pornography in his office, despite being a respected figure in the education sector. The image shows Barr surfing for explicit content while on-duty, sparking a serious breach of the school's standards. The photograph was taken by a student and shared on social media, leading to Barr's resignation from the role. The incident has raised questions about the school's handling of the situation and its ability to maintain high standards.

Francis Pusok, a 30-year-old man, was arrested and beaten by police in a two-and-a-half hour horseback chase in southern California. He was initially handcuffed for nearly 100% of the beating, which included 30 punches and kicks, and suffered severe injuries, including a bruised black eye. Pusok fled his home after being arrested for identity theft charges, leading police on a 2.5-hour chase. The incident has raised concerns about police brutality and excessive force, particularly given Pusok's prior run-ins with law enforcement. Pusok's pregnant girlfriend, Jolene Bindner, expressed worry about potential retaliation against them due to previous allegations of threats made by police.

Mohammed Emwazi, also known as "Jihadi John", a former British ISIS recruiter, met with Hizb ut-Tahrir while studying at Westminster University. He later became embroiled in conflicts with the group, including attacking activists in Syria. Emwazi was linked to several individuals connected to ISIS, including a would-be MP, Maajid Nawaz, who was jailed for his role in radical Islamist groups. Nawaz attempted to touch a naked stripper at a London nightclub, sparking outrage.

A new tropical fruit called the 'Bouea macrophylla' or'mango plum' is being stocked by Marks & Spencer in the UK. This unique fruit combines characteristics of both mangoes and plums, featuring a bright orange edible skin and a sweet taste similar to an Alphonso mango. The fruit is smaller than a mango and has a softer texture, making it easy to eat. Marks & Spencer is one of several retailers stocking the fruit, which is also known as the 'plango'.

A statue of British colonialist Cecil Rhodes, a proponent of imperialism, is set to be removed from the University of Cape Town in South Africa due to protests over its presence. The statue, which depicts Rhodes as a symbol of white supremacy, has been vandalized multiple times since its installation. The university council voted to remove the statue after months of protests from black students and staff, citing discomfort caused by its presence. The decision comes amid growing tensions over monuments of historical figures in South Africa, particularly those associated with colonialism and racism.

Hannah Bluck, a 18-year-old Welsh footballer, has had her promising career cut short due to a rare condition called avascular necrosis, where her leg bone died due to a lack of blood supply. This condition, affecting the distal tibia, made it impossible for her to continue playing for Wales' youth national teams. After undergoing treatment, Hannah's leg bone collapsed, causing her to miss out on potential opportunities to join the senior team. Her family, led by her mother Kerstin, worked tirelessly to find a solution, eventually securing an appointment with a specialist in London. With ongoing rehabilitation efforts, Hannah remains hopeful of returning to the pitch and pursuing her dreams of becoming a professional footballer.

Edinson Cavani, the Paris Saint-Germain forward, has denied rumors suggesting a rift between him and teammate Zlatan Ibrahimovic, insisting that the issue lies solely with being played out of position. Despite reports of tension between them, Cavani claims to have a respectful relationship with Ibrahimovic. Cavani has expressed frustration at being relegated to a front three role, which he feels doesn't suit his preferred position. He has also revealed that he has not scored much in Ligue 1 this season, fueling speculation about his future at the club. The match against Marseille saw Ibrahimovic celebrate PSG's third goal, while Cavani challenged him in the game.

The England U-17 team, led by coach John Peacock, has announced its squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship. The team includes several talented young players from Premier League clubs such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Arsenal's Chris Willock. The squad also features defenders like Danny Collinge and Reece Oxford, while midfielders Trent Arnold and Daniel Wright round out the group. The team faces off against Italy, Holland, and Ireland in Group D, with the final match taking place in Bulgaria on May 7.

Fireball Cinnamon Whisky, a fast-growing liquor brand, has seen its sales double since 2011 and has become the sixth-most popular liquor brand in the US, surpassing brands like Jim Beam and Jagermeister. The brand gained momentum thanks to its unique flavor profile, which combines Canadian whisky with sweetener and spicy cinnamon, making it a favorite among young drinkers. Despite its rapid rise, Fireball has faced criticism from whiskey enthusiasts who prefer traditional spirits, and some have accused the brand of being a fad. However, Fireball continues to thrive, with over 85,000 followers on social media and a loyal customer base, particularly among young adults.

Researchers conducted a study involving 11 male athletes who ate either fast food or a standard sports nutrition supplement after a 90-minute endurance workout. The study found that eating fast food resulted in similar performance outcomes to consuming a standard sports nutrition product, despite having different macronutrient profiles. The study's lead researcher, Michael Cramer, a graduate student at the University of Montana, suggested that short bursts of intense exercise can be beneficial for muscle recovery. The findings suggest that incorporating fast food into a recovery routine may be beneficial, but further research is needed to understand its long-term effects.

Gael Monfils defeated Roger Federer 6-4, 7-6 in a thrilling match at the Monte Carlo Masters. Monfils showed flashes of brilliance throughout the contest, displaying athleticism and shot-making skills that left Federer frustrated. Despite being down 4-4, Monfils took control of the second set, winning several crucial points and eventually taking the tiebreaker. In the final set, Monfils' determination paid off as he hit 22 winners to Federer's 17, securing a stunning victory. Monfils celebrated his win by shaking hands with Federer, who ultimately bowed out of the tournament.

Rev. Al Sharpton delivered a sermon at Charity Missionary Baptist Church in South Carolina, criticizing the handling of the Walter Scott shooting and calling for reform in national policing legislation. He praised Mayor Keith Summey for firing the officer responsible for the shooting, Michael Slager, and urged the nation to address issues of racial tension and police brutality. Sharpton also criticized the police department's use of excessive force and denied allegations that Scott's family had barred him from attending his funeral due to media attention. The shooting occurred when Scott, a 50-year-old veteran, was shot and killed by Officer Michael Slager while fleeing a traffic stop.

A report by Stewart Brand suggests that while there are concerns about the potential for mass extinctions due to human activities, the actual trend is opposite. Despite these threats, the planet is experiencing an increase in biodiversity, with many species recovering after being thought to be extinct. Conservation efforts, such as reintroducing extinct species and eradicating invasive species, can lead to positive outcomes. Climate change may pose a challenge, but it is unlikely to cause widespread extinctions, and many species are adapting to survive.

ISIS, a self-proclaimed caliphate, controls various aspects of governance in Iraq and Syria, including issuing official documents such as birth certificates, vaccination schedules, and rental agreements. Under Sharia law conditions, the group bans certain activities deemed un-Islamic, such as archaeology, hotel management, and entertainment, particularly those considered idol-worshiping. Despite its brutal reputation, ISIS presents itself as a more just and fair alternative to the previous rulers, implementing policies like lowering prices for basic necessities like bread and regulating entertainment. The group's goal is to establish a strict Islamic state, distinguishing itself from neighboring countries like Afghanistan and Pakistan, where the Taliban prohibits vaccinations due to concerns over polio.

A triple tragedy unfolded in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, when a 2-year-old boy was run over by a van driven by Archie Brown Jr, who was then shot and killed. The 15-year-old boy who was riding in the van was also shot and later died. An unidentified gunman shot Brown Jr at the scene, killing him, and another 15-year-old boy was also shot and died shortly after being taken to the hospital. The motive behind the shooting remains unclear, but Milwaukee police suspect it may be related to the death of the young boy.

The odds on the new royal baby being a girl have dropped significantly after a Scottish bookmaker revealed that 90% of bets were in favor of a female child. The betting market has shifted towards a girl, with names such as Alice, Victoria, and Alice Maud Marie gaining popularity. The odds suggest that the Duchess of Cambridge may give birth to a girl, while other favorites include James, Arthur, and Prince Philip. The betting market is highly speculative, but the odds indicate that the chances of a girl are currently higher than a boy.

Holly Willoughby and Davina McCall, two British TV personalities, have teamed up for a new campaign celebrating finding the perfect hair shade with Garnier Nutrisse. They starred in a photo shoot showcasing their matching 10.01 multi-tonal blonde hair color. The duo, both 47 and 34 respectively, have partnered with the brand to promote its products. Their collaboration marks their first joint appearance together, and they've also launched a new range of vintage-inspired clothing for babies.

Ellanora Arthur Baidoo, a Brooklyn woman, is seeking a divorce from her husband Victor Sena Blood-Dzraku after being unable to find him to serve her with divorce papers due to his refusal to comply. She used Facebook to try to serve him, but was unsuccessful, and instead asked the New York judge to consider alternative methods such as sending the papers via social media. A judge ruled that social media platforms like Facebook can be used to deliver divorce papers, and Baidoo will have the option to proceed with a "divorce by default" if she cannot find her husband. Her lawyer, Andrew Spinnell, says Baidoo is simply trying to move on with her life and get a divorce.

The Holy Shroud, a 14-foot-long linen cloth believed to be the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, has gone on public display in Turin, Italy after being absent from view for five years. The cloth features an image of a man who appears to have been crucified and is thought to represent Jesus Christ. It is considered a symbol of Christ's suffering and is valued by the Catholic Church for its historical significance. The shroud is expected to attract millions of visitors during its six-month run, particularly around June 24, when Pope Francis is set to visit the city.

A new luxury mansion in Mayfair, London, has hit the market for £25 million. This four-bedroom property, previously a milking parlor, has been transformed into a modern residence with an indoor swimming pool, gym, and cinema room. Located on a site that dates back to the 19th century, the property boasts impressive artwork and high-end finishes throughout. With its unique blend of old and new, this mansion offers a truly one-of-a-kind living experience.

Aidan Turner, the star of the popular BBC period drama Poldark, will reprise his role as Captain Ross Poldark in a second series. The show, which follows Ross's journey after returning home from the American War of Independence, has gained significant attention and acclaim, attracting 8.1 million viewers per episode. The series, based on Winston Graham's novels, explores themes of love, family, and loyalty. With the success of the first season, the show has become a new phenomenon, making it one of the top-rated shows on BBC1.

A gastrointestinal illness has affected 100 people on the Celebrity Infinity cruise ship, which departed from San Diego on March 29 and arrived in Puerto Vallarta on April 10. The CDC has confirmed the outbreak, with 95 passengers suffering from vomiting and diarrhea. This is not the first time the ship has experienced such an issue, as it has had two previous outbreaks in 2006 and 2013. The CDC has increased cleaning and disinfection procedures on board and taken samples for further testing.

Electronic devices such as smartphones, cars, and appliances can now feature tactile interfaces that provide a new level of interaction experience. Technology developed by UltraHaptics uses ultrasound to create three-dimensional shapes out of thin air, allowing users to feel tactile sensations while seeing virtual objects. By combining this technology with existing interfaces, such as buttons and screens, manufacturers can create immersive experiences that enhance the overall user experience. Companies like Apple and Google are already exploring the potential applications of UltraHaptics' technology, which includes creating custom buttons, dashboard controls, and even interactive displays.

Jodie Barden, a 28-year-old mother of two young daughters, Ella and Chloe, suffers from Cockayne Syndrome, a rare genetic disorder characterized by premature aging, underdevelopment, and sensitivity to sunlight. Due to the rarity of the disease, her daughters' life expectancy is limited to 12 years. Despite the challenges, Jodie and her husband, Luke, have planned their daughters' funerals and are working towards making the most of their time together. The couple has raised funds for the Cockayne Syndrome charity and has taken part in various activities, including skydiving and visiting Disney parks, to honor their daughters' memories.

A 11-year-old boy named Damon Muller has a rare autoimmune disease called Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM), which causes severe inflammation and swelling in his muscles, leading to significant growth issues. Since his diagnosis, Damon has experienced rapid growth, nearly doubling in size, and severe swelling in his body, particularly in his thighs and lower back. A rash on his face and neck has become infected, causing discomfort and making it hard for him to breathe. His parents describe the situation as "very scary" and note that their son's condition requires strict treatment with steroids and a chemotherapy-like drug, limiting his outdoor activities.

Chelsy Davy, a 29-year-old Zimbabwean socialite, attended a London restaurant launch event for The Ivy Chelsea Garden, where she showed off her stylish side by wearing a white layered chiffon top paired with navy trousers and tan wedges. The outing marked a change from her previous more casual style, as she took a step towards a more sophisticated look. Chelsy was accompanied by friend Irene Forte, who also attended the event. The two have remained close friends since their split from Prince Harry in 2010.

A lack of iron, especially in women, can lead to hair loss due to reduced oxygen delivery to the hair follicle. Taking iron pills may not be effective in treating hair loss, according to some doctors. To promote hair growth, consuming enough protein is essential, as hair consists of protein. Some research suggests that certain supplements like l-lysine and Alpecin caffeine liquid hair energiser may help stimulate human hair growth. However, more research is needed to confirm their effectiveness.

Orangutan Suma, aged 36, underwent a thorough health examination at Melbourne Zoo due to painful arthritis. The examination involved taking X-rays and performing a full check-up, including her ears, teeth, and eyes. To alleviate her pain, Suma received a steroid injection administered by an orthopedic surgeon. This treatment allowed veterinarians to assess the progression of the condition and provide further care.

Louis Tomlinson, a member of the British boy band One Direction, was spotted having a wild night in London's Soho Hotel with five girls, including a woman who joked that he might be "one Direction" in a Snapchat video. The photos show Louis back in his hotel room, where he rolled a suspicious cigarette and was seen playing air guitar. The snaps also appear to show Louis returning to the hotel after a night of partying with his friends, including fellow bandmates Harry Styles, Liam Payne, and Niall Horan. The wild night came after Louis broke off his four-year relationship with his girlfriend, Eleanor Calder, in March.

A series of old photographs taken between 1900 and 1911 during the Qing dynasty showcase Beijing's iconic landmarks, offering a rare glimpse into the city's past. These historic images reveal a quieter scene compared to modern-day Beijing, which is one of the most populous cities in the world. The photographs feature many of Beijing's most famous sites, including the Temple of Heaven, Summer Palace, and the Forbidden City, which attract millions of visitors each year. The images also include portraits of ordinary people, showcasing everyday life in ancient Beijing.

Australian homeowners are experiencing record-breaking profits on their properties due to a surge in sales, particularly in capital cities like Sydney, Perth, and Melbourne. Homes that were originally sold for below market value are now selling for significantly higher prices, with some examples reaching over $3 million. In contrast, homes that were originally bought for lower prices are still selling for more than double their original purchase price. The Western Australian market is notable for its high retention rates, with homes staying in the market for nearly 12 years or more, while in other regions, such as New South Wales, homes tend to sell more frequently.

Tony Pulis, the manager of West Bromwich Albion, wore a traditional suit and tie to the match against Crystal Palace despite having previously worn a cap. He insisted on this uniform as a personal preference, citing his desire to be close to the action. The 2-0 victory secured West Brom's 36-point lead in the Premier League, ensuring their safety. James Morrison scored both goals, while Craig Gardner added one. This marked a significant improvement in form for the Baggies, who had been struggling to find consistency.

Steve Parish celebrated a great moment at Crystal Palace after their 2-1 win over Manchester City, posing for a photo with Palace manager Alan Pardew, England boss Roy Hodgson, and former Rolling Stones member Bill Wyman. Wyman, who has been a lifelong fan of the club, was among the many supporters in attendance. Parish described the occasion as "a great moment" and praised Wyman's dedication to the team. Hodgson, who is also a former Palace player, was impressed by Wyman's knowledge of the club's history. The win marked a significant victory for Palace, who were led by manager Pardew and featuring several notable English players, including Jason Puncheon and Wilfried Zaha.

The Solar Impulse 2, a single-seater experimental plane, has been grounded due to bad weather in China, forcing a two-and-a-half-week stay. Pilot Bertrand Piccard and co-pilot Andre Borschberg have spent weeks preparing for the plane's journey, which aims to prove the power of renewable energy and inspire innovation. Despite technical issues, the plane remains operational, but the team is eager to continue their mission. The plane's destination is Chongqing, China, and the team hopes to depart again soon, with a possible window opening on Tuesday.

Jordan Spieth visited the observation deck of the Empire State Building after winning the Masters tournament, where he was presented with the green jacket by Bubba Watson. Spieth achieved a career-best score of 18 under par to break Tiger Woods' record and become the championship's second-youngest winner of all time. Spieth's victory marked a significant milestone in his career, surpassing Justin Rose's record of four PGA Tour wins before age 22. Spieth's impressive performance earned praise from Justin Rose, who called him "one of the best" and noted that he is "way more mature" than many of his peers. Spieth's current position of No. 2 in the world is a testament to his consistent excellence throughout the season.

David Cameron's home features a stylish kitchen where he enjoys using a cafetiere coffee machine and owns a collection of cookbooks, including titles by Mary Berry and William Hanson. His home also boasts an Aga stove, which William considers a "good status symbol." He favors a traditional setup with a reed diffuser and a single tap, while having a large number of plain loo paper rolls and a two-tap bathroom. Overall, Cameron's home reflects his upper-class background, with a focus on quality materials and classic furnishings.

Andy Murray tied the knot with British tennis star Kim Sears at Dunblane Cathedral on Saturday. The ceremony was attended by hundreds of fans and was conducted by Reverend Colin Renwick. The happy couple exchanged rings and promised to love each other forever, surrounded by their families and closest friends. The wedding preparations were underway, with florists setting up decorations and fans gathering outside the cathedral.

Alastair Cook played a decent innings against the West Indies, showing signs of improvement in his game. His front foot is now slightly open, but he struggled to adjust to the new stance against India. This led to some awkward moments, such as when his front foot landed outside the line of the stumps. However, Cook showed flashes of his old self, particularly in the nets session where he appeared to be moving better. Despite struggling against the West Indies, Cook remains a valuable asset to the team.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting their final contract offer. He has been with the club for seven years, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. Alves's agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that he had turned down a three-year contract extension, citing dissatisfaction with the terms. The move is expected to spark a transfer frenzy, with several top clubs interested in signing him.

A 73-year-old man named Robin Ellis was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes in 1999 at the age of 58 after being diagnosed with type 1 diabetes due to his mother's death from a heart attack caused by 30 years of type 1 diabetes. Despite being overweight and having a sedentary lifestyle, Robin has managed to retain his physical fitness thanks to a combination of dietary changes and regular exercise. His doctor attributes his success to eliminating sugar and refined carbohydrates from his diet and increasing his physical activity. With the help of a cookbook author, Robin has become a passionate advocate for healthy eating and lifestyle changes, writing cookbooks and leading workshops on the topic.

Aaron Hernandez, a former New England Patriots tight end, has been transferred to the Souza-Baranowski Correctional Center in Shirley, Massachusetts, after being convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison. He was convicted of killing Odin Lloyd in 2013, a 27-year-old man who was dating the sister of Hernandez's fiancée. Hernandez was initially housed at Cedar Junction prison before being transferred to Souza-Baranowski due to concerns over his safety. The correction center is a maximum-security facility housing around 1,000 inmates, including those serving life sentences. Hernandez will be housed in a cell block reserved for those serving life sentences, along with other notable inmates.

A 35-year-old man named Jamie Robbins stole £1,600 from a convenience store in Birmingham, where he had previously worked. He handed himself into police after a year without being caught due to his preference for life inside rather than out. Robbins claimed he was seeking a new life behind bars, but later revealed that his girlfriend had become pregnant and no longer wanted him to face imprisonment. He was sentenced to four-and-a-half years in prison for robbery and possession of a bladed article.

A pregnant camel named Injaz, who was cloned from the ovarian cells of a slaughtered camel in 2009, has given birth to a healthy calf. Scientists claim that Injaz is the world's first cloned camel, conceived naturally, and is expected to give birth again soon. Cloning allows for the preservation of the genetics of the camel population, which is valued for its use in racing, transportation, and dairy production. New gene editing techniques, such as CRISPR, hold promise for modifying human embryos to prevent inherited diseases.

Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson revealed why he thinks Cristiano Ronaldo is better than Lionel Messi during an interview with John Parrott on the BBC's World Championship at the Crucible. Ferguson praised Ronaldo's versatility, speed, and bravery, citing his ability to play anywhere on the pitch. He also mentioned that Ronaldo's humility and willingness to learn made him more likable than Messi. Ferguson expressed admiration for Ronaldo's achievements, saying he could play for any team and score a hat-trick. Ferguson's comments were met with applause from the audience, who thought he was right.

A bus carrying Fenerbahce players and coaching staff was attacked while traveling from a match in Trabzon to Istanbul. The driver was severely injured and taken to hospital after being struck by gunfire. A shotgun was used in the attack, and the driver appeared to have been hit by a bullet. Fenerbahce's midfielder Ludovic Obraniak was also injured and taken to hospital with a suspected heart problem. The incident occurred near the city of Trabzon, where the team bus was heading to return to Istanbul.

Nicola Ferguson Sturgeon, the leader of the Scottish National Party (SNP), made a strong impression during a recent TV debate, showcasing her poise and charisma. She addressed a large audience, including those outside Scotland, and was praised for her ability to connect with them. With her newfound popularity, she could potentially wield significant influence over future UK politics, particularly if the SNP wins the upcoming general election. This could lead to a shift in the balance of power in Westminster, making her a force to be reckoned with.

Declan Fitzpatrick, a 31-year-old Irish prop, has announced his retirement from professional rugby due to medical reasons. The 98-time capped player suffered multiple concussions over the years, prompting a referral to a neurologist who advised him to stop playing. Fitzpatrick expressed gratitude to Ulster Rugby and the IRFU for their support throughout his career. His decision comes as he looks forward to pursuing other interests.

FLIR Systems Inc., a defense contractor based in Oregon, has agreed to pay $9.5 million to settle bribery charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) related to gifts and expenses given to Middle Eastern government officials. The SEC alleged that FLIR's CEO Andy Teich and two employees, Stephen Timms and Yasser Ramahi, accepted bribes in exchange for luxury items such as watches and vacations. The company will report to the SEC on its compliance with anti-bribery laws over the next two years. As part of the settlement, FLIR will pay $7 million in profits from sales influenced by the gifts, while also agreeing to cooperate with the investigation.

Floyd Mayweather Jr. is preparing for his highly anticipated $300 million mega fight against Manny Pacquiao on May 2. Inside his training camp, Mayweather is focusing on perfecting his skills ahead of the big event. A short promotional video by Showtime captures a glimpse into his intense preparation, showcasing his dedication to the sport. Mayweather weighs in close to the 147-pound welterweight limit, having recently dropped below it. This marks one of the biggest fights in boxing history, with all three major sanctioning bodies involved.

A 58-year-old woman, Diwalinen Vankar, bravely fought off a 13ft-long crocodile that grabbed her 19-year-old daughter Kanta's legs while they were washing clothes in the Vishwamitri River in India. The incident occurred when a mugger crocodile attacked Kanta, dragging her into the river, causing a severe leg injury. Diwalinen Vankar used a wooden paddle to fight off the crocodile, ultimately freeing her daughter after 10 minutes of intense struggle. The mother's bravery and quick thinking saved her daughter's life, and she has since received treatment for her injuries.

The article discusses the 20 greatest shots ever seen at Augusta National Golf Club, counting down from No. 20 to No. 1. These iconic moments showcase incredible golfing feats, including notable wins, comebacks, and record-breaking shots. The article highlights various players who achieved greatness, such as Mark O'Meara's two birdies, Charl Schwartzel's epic birdies, and Seve Ballesteros's dramatic clutch performance. Other notable mentions include Billy Joe Patton's hole-in-one, Nick Faldo's nerveless putts, and Louis Oosthuizen's record-breaking drive.

Jaclyn Methuen, a former "runaway bride" who nearly left her husband Ryan Ranellone at the altar due to his perceived lack of attractiveness, embarks on a honeymoon with him in Puerto Rico. However, their romantic getaway takes an awkward turn when they struggle to connect and discuss their differences. Meanwhile, Davina Kullar, another newlywed, faces marital problems with her husband Sean Varricchio, who accuses her of misinterpreting his words. In contrast, Jaclyn Methuen finds herself stuck in the "friend zone" with Ryan Ranellone, who is growing increasingly frustrated with her refusal to call him by his name. Tonight's episode promises to reveal more tension and conflict between these couples as they navigate their relationships.

Mullah Mohammed Omar, the founder of the Taliban's self-declared Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan, remains the leader of the group despite rumors suggesting otherwise. Born in 1960 in a village in Afghanistan's Kandahar province, Omar studied at a religious school before joining the mujahedeen rebellion against the Soviet occupation. After the Taliban took control of Kabul in 1996, Omar allegedly went into hiding, sparking speculation about his fate. The Taliban recently released a biography, which offers a detailed account of Omar's life, including his daily routine and leadership style, in an effort to dispel rumors of his disappearance.

The NFL investigation into the New England Patriots' alleged use of deflated footballs began in January after the team lost to the Indianapolis Colts in the AFC Championship game. The investigation, led by attorney Ted Wells, aimed to determine if the Patriots intentionally deflated the footballs used in the game. The league hired several firms, including Renaissance Associates, to review electronic and video footage. The investigation is ongoing, and the NFL has yet to release a timeline for completion and findings. The Patriots could face fines and penalties, including a loss of draft picks, if the investigation finds evidence of wrongdoing.

A 28-year-old woman named Bianca Gascoigne, daughter of football legend Paul Gascoigne, was mugged by a group of eight thugs on their bikes in central London. Her phone containing private texts was stolen, leaving her devastated. The attackers allegedly tried to steal her bag before fleeing when she fought back. The incident occurred on Tuesday afternoon, and the police are investigating. The muggers are described as "lowlifes" and are believed to have been targeting the area due to the presence of a former football star.

Aberdeen striker Adam Rooney is determined to prevent his team's season from ending with a disappointing outcome, having won the Scottish Premiership title four consecutive times before. Rooney wants to ensure that the current eight-point gap between Aberdeen and Celtic remains intact if they secure a fourth successive title. With a strong squad and a talented young player in Graeme Shinnie, who has impressed in the Scottish Cup, Aberdeen is confident of adding more points to their tally. However, they know that Celtic will be looking to bounce back from a heavy defeat on the road to the title, and Rooney expects them to push hard for victory. If Aberdeen can maintain their momentum, they may be able to secure a fourth consecutive title.

Marion "Suge" Knight, a former rap mogul, was ordered to stand trial for murder and other charges related to a deadly hit-and-run incident involving two men, Terry Carter and Cle Sloan, who were killed in a confrontation on the set of the biopic "Straight Outta Compton". Knight, 49, faces up to life in prison if convicted. His defense team argued that he was the victim, claiming that Sloan was the aggressor, while prosecutors presented evidence suggesting that Knight used his car as a deadly weapon. Knight's bail was reduced from $25 million to $10 million, and he will face one count of murder, one count of attempted murder, and one count of hit-and-run. Knight suffered from diabetes and clotting issues before the incident, which may have weakened his physical condition.

Hillary Clinton met with three young Iowans at a coffee shop in LeClaire, Iowa, allegedly organized by her campaign staff, including Troy Price, who drove them to the event. The meeting was reportedly a "roundtable" discussion, but sources say it was more of a scripted event to promote her image as a spontaneous and relatable figure. This move could harm Clinton's reputation if seen as insincere or manipulative given her nascent campaign. The meeting was attended by several high-profile figures, including Vice President Joe Biden, who was present despite being out of town on official business.

A new HIV self-testing kit has been launched in the UK, enabling people to test their HIV status at home using a finger-prick blood sample. This 99.7% accurate test allows individuals to know their HIV status quickly and discreetly, reducing the risk of transmission. Those who remain undiagnosed despite having HIV face a higher risk of complications and death if left untreated. The test requires positive results to be confirmed by a healthcare professional, while those in high-risk groups should test regularly.

A group of four former gang members, including Dimas "Diablo" Deleon, who was once the leader of the Nuestra Familia gang, have been housed in a Special Needs Housing Unit at the California Department of Corrections. This unit provides a safe environment for individuals who want to leave their gang affiliation behind, allowing them to reintegrate into society. The unit is designed to reduce racial violence and segregation within prisons, while also providing a sense of community and support for those trying to leave the gang lifestyle. Despite its exclusivity, the unit allows inmates to participate in activities like basketball and receive job training, offering a glimmer of hope for redemption.

A personal injury claims company, Direct Assist, has been fined £80,000 by the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) for allegedly causing nuisance calls to households despite receiving numerous complaints about its practice. The company instructed its staff to use phone numbers from the Telephone Preference Service (TPS), which includes those who have opted out of unwanted calls, leading to repeated calls to individuals who did not give consent. This behavior is considered a breach of the UK's data protection laws and has caused significant distress to many affected households. The ICO has taken action against the company, which has since gone into liquidation and intends to seek compensation for any harm caused.

Jose Mourinho's defensive prowess has been instrumental in securing multiple Premier League titles for Chelsea, with statistics showing he holds the best clean sheets percentage record in the league with 101 from 189 matches. This achievement surpasses Rafa Benitez's previous record of 53.4%. The Portuguese manager has consistently demonstrated his ability to shut out opponents, while also boasting the highest goal-conceding average among all managers in the league. In contrast, Arsene Wenger has maintained an impressive defensive record, conceding just 277 clean sheets in 708 games. Both Mourinho and Wenger have achieved remarkable defensive success, with Mourinho holding the title of best clean sheets percentage record in the league.

A 15-year-old girl from Cape Town, South Africa, was detained by authorities at Cape Town International Airport after they received information that she was planning to join the terrorist group ISIS. She had been using social media to interact with strangers and read materials suggesting she wanted to join the group. Authorities found her on a flight bound for Johannesburg, where she was subsequently secured and released back to her family's care. The incident highlights concerns about the growing threat of terrorism among young people, particularly those under the age of 18.

Ben Powers, an actor known for his roles in the classic CBS sitcom "Good Times", passed away on April 6 after suffering a fatal injury during a church ceremony. He played the character Keith Anderson on the show from 1978 to 1979. Powers also appeared in various other TV shows, including "Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer", "Cheech & Chong's Next Movie", and "The Man Who Loved Women". He attended the Rhode Island School of Design for art and later pursued a career in stand-up comedy.

A 39-year-old man, identified as Karl Kay, was shot multiple times by an unknown assailant in his mother's Altona Meadows home in Melbourne. The shooting occurred around 2am on Sunday, resulting in the death of the man. The motive behind the attack remains unclear, with police investigating whether it was a targeted or gang-related incident. The man's mother and others present at the scene assisted police in the investigation.

A photographer visited the Ulusaba Game Reserve in South Africa's Sabi Sands, where he encountered a 4,500lb horned rhino while trying to capture its image. The reserve is owned by Sir Richard Branson and features a stunning location with a "perfect lookout point" due to its ancient Shangaan warriors' preference for it. The photographer managed to get some great shots of various wildlife, including a 6-month-old leopard cub playing with an impala antelope. The trip included photographing a 1,000 rhinos killed by poachers in the previous year, which highlights the importance of conservation efforts in the region.

George Lucas, the creator of Star Wars, has announced plans to build an affordable housing complex on his 1,039-acre ranch in Marin County, California. The project, valued at $200m, will feature 224 homes for low-income families and 104 apartments for pensioners. The development, dubbed the Lucas Valley Community, aims to address the issue of unaffordable housing in the area. Lucas dropped plans for a film studio on the same land in 2012 due to opposition from neighbors, but now seeks to rectify the situation.

A great grey owl swooped silently over snowy fields in Ontario, Canada, capturing a dramatic image of itself attacking a tiny mouse. The bird's exceptional hearing and stealth allowed it to stalk its prey from high above, eventually striking with lightning speed and precision. The owl's impressive wingspan of five feet enabled it to make a swift and silent landing, as seen in a photograph taken by photographer Marc Latremouille. The bird's sharp claws proved effective in catching its unsuspecting victim, showcasing its predatory prowess.

Manchester City defender Bacary Sagna has expressed no regrets about leaving Arsenal last summer, despite the team's disappointing start to the season. He joined City in July, where they finished fourth in the Premier League, while Arsenal secured the league title. Sagna believes Manchester City will return to winning ways under manager Manuel Pellegrini and hopes to help them secure a top-four spot. With the Premier League title already being claimed by Chelsea, Sagna thinks City can still challenge for the title. His decision to leave Arsenal remains unchanged, with Sagna stating he would choose to join City again if given the opportunity.

Nigel Farage suggested that David Cameron secretly uses hair dye to try to regain youth, citing his own experience as a reason for being "jealous" of the Prime Minister's ability to appear younger despite struggling with greying. The suggestion came during a heated exchange between the two politicians after their televised debate. Cameron denied any involvement in hair dyeing, but Farage claimed he was "shaken" by the revelation. Farage expressed concern that some people might be worried about Cameron's vanity, suggesting that others may be more concerned about aging than he is.
