Veteran World War II hero Robert Clark, 96, has been refused funding to stay in his own home due to a lack of funds from the local council. The council claims it cannot afford to provide a live-in carer for him, despite receiving an emergency grant from Help for Heroes to cover his care costs. Clark, who suffers from severe anxiety and is blind, deaf in one ear and reliant on a wheelchair, wants to stay in his own home, but the council says it is too expensive. The council has set a cap of £451 per week for a care home, but Clark's family is seeking alternative options, including using the Help for Heroes quick reaction fund.

FC Chernomorets Odessa is selling luxury houses near the sea as part of an effort to cover their salary debts. The club is offering these houses to its players in exchange for reduced salaries. The move comes amid a severe financial crisis, with the club facing potential relegation and disqualification from UEFA competitions if they don't settle their outstanding payments. Players who remain with the club will see their monthly salaries significantly reduced. The club currently sits 11th in the Ukrainian Premier League, just 12 points behind bottom side Karpaty.

Kestutis Martuzevicius, a Lithuanian gangster, was accused of 22 crimes, including two murders, and is currently wanted in the UK. He repeatedly stalled efforts to extradite him due to mental health concerns, claiming he was depressed and would face retaliation from alleged foreign criminals in Lithuania. Martuzevicius was initially detained in Lithuania in 1996 and later transferred to Belmarsh Prison in London, where he remained until his return in 2019. Despite facing a lengthy extradition process, Martuzevicius continued to claim he was unfit to stand trial due to his mental health issues, sparking criticism from judges who deemed his case "manifestly ill-founded".

A vigilante group of individuals, allegedly posing as children, have been accused of targeting vulnerable teenagers and men in the North-West region of England. They claimed to be posing as underage girls to lure victims into meeting them, but were later revealed to be using tactics such as filming and threatening violence to control their victims. One teenager was beaten up by the group, who tricked him into believing he was meeting an underage girl in a church car park. The teenager reported the incident to police, who subsequently arrested the group and charged them with various offenses related to grooming and assault.

Real Madrid's Champions League starters returned to training after a break, with Isco and Alvaro Arbeloa participating alongside regular first team players Pepe and Sami Khedira. The team also included Javier Hernandez and Lucas Silva, while Isco kept the ball from Fabio Coentrao during a session. Real Madrid will now look to bounce back from a disappointing 0-0 draw against Atletico in the Champions League. They will face Malaga in La Liga on Saturday before returning to action against Atletico again next Wednesday.

David Hibbitt, a 33-year-old man from Stoke-on-Trent, England, was diagnosed with stage-three bowel cancer in July 2012. Despite receiving chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgery, he was told he had only 18 months and five years to live. However, after researching alternative treatments, including cannabis oil, he made the decision to try it, which led to a miraculous recovery. With the support of his fiancée, Heather, and a successful marriage, he is now celebrating his five-year anniversary of living cancer-free.

On Earth Day, President Barack Obama visited Everglades National Park in Florida to highlight the impact of climate change on the region's ecosystems and economies. The park, which is threatened by rising sea levels and saltwater intrusion, serves as a symbol of the devastating effects of climate change. Obama emphasized the need for immediate action to combat global warming and protect America's "national treasures" like the Everglades. His visit coincided with a trip aboard Air Force One, where he met with scientists and conservationists, including Bill Nye "the Science Guy." As part of his Earth Day commemoration, Obama urged Americans to take responsibility for protecting the environment and ensuring the long-term health of the planet.

Javier Hernandez returned to training with Real Madrid after a disappointing season, despite failing to secure a permanent transfer deal. He had previously signed a one-season loan agreement with the club worth around £15 million, allowing them to keep him until the end of the season. This means that other teams can now bid for the Mexican striker. With interest from several clubs, including West Ham, Southampton, Newcastle, and Lazio, United have given up on signing Hernandez outright.

Bonnie Doll, a 28-year-old Australian gamer, rose to fame playing Call Of Duty and has built a massive following on Twitch, with over 45,000 global followers. Born in Sweden, she moved to Australia in 2007 and began live streaming on Twitch, initially playing Call Of Duty with friends before becoming a solo streamer. With over 1 million views on her channel, Bonnie earns a significant income from subscriptions, donations, and ad revenue. She works from home, using her Xbox 1 and 360, and enjoys interacting with her large community of fans, who appreciate her authenticity and humor. Despite facing online harassment, Bonnie remains focused on building her brand and engaging with her loyal viewers.

YouTube is introducing a new paid subscription service called YouTube Music Key, which allows users to access music videos without ads. This service is part of YouTube's effort to provide additional revenue streams for creators. The service will allow users to watch videos offline and without ads, and will include features such as personalized recommendations and improved discoverability. The service is available for a monthly fee, with prices starting at £7.99 in the UK and $7.99 in the US.

Marion "Suge" Knight, a former rapper and music mogul, has been hospitalized after a judge ruled he will stand trial on murder and attempted-murder charges related to a fatal hit-and-run incident involving two men in January. Knight, 49, allegedly struck and killed Terry Carter, 55, and seriously injured another man, Cle "Bone" Sloan, 45, who was left with severe injuries. Knight faces up to life in prison if convicted, despite having prior felony convictions for armed robbery and assault with a gun. Sloan, a former gang member, testified under duress about the incident, claiming he was only on the stand due to a Fifth Amendment right to avoid self-incrimination. Knight's court hearings have been dramatic, with multiple medical conditions and complaints of weight loss and vision problems.

Bailey Murrill, a 7-year-old girl from Denton, Texas, was unexpectedly paralyzed for 11 days due to an inexplicable condition. Her favorite nurse, Becky Murrill, surprised her by getting up from her wheelchair and standing for the first time, causing Bailey to scream with joy and burst into tears. The incident was captured on video, which has since gone viral, garnering over 1 million views. The cause of Bailey's paralysis remains unknown, but her mother, Becky Murrill, expressed gratitude for the support and well-wishes received during her recovery.

Julian Assange, founder of WikiLeaks, has agreed to be interviewed by Swedish prosecutors in London after a change in their approach due to the statute of limitations on the alleged crimes. He had been holed up in the Ecuadorian Embassy in London since June 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden. The Swedish authorities will now seek permission to conduct the interview at the embassy, which may lead to Assange being present in Sweden for a potential trial. Assange denies the allegations and fears extradition to the US, where he faces the death penalty.

Pete Bennett, a former Big Brother star, has revealed that he is now homeless after struggling with homelessness due to his struggles with drug addiction. He was a winner of the show in 2006 and has spoken publicly about his experiences with ketamine use and its impact on his life. Pete has been open about his past behavior, including his tumultuous relationships and his decision to leave the Big Brother house. He has since sought treatment and is now working towards rebuilding his life, including pursuing acting roles.

Borussia Dortmund won a comfortable 6-2 victory over relegation-threatened Paderborn at Signal Iduna Park, moving into third place in the Bundesliga table. The win lifted the club to eighth position, leaving them with a realistic chance of qualifying for European competition. Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang scored twice, while Shinji Kagawa added another goal. The win marked a significant improvement for Dortmund, who had struggled under manager Jurgen Klopp's departure. The match saw a Borussia Dortmund fan hold up a sign thanking Klopp for his achievements.

A North Korean defector in South Korea is launching hundreds of balloons carrying DVDs and leaflets into North Korean territory, despite warnings from authorities about the potential consequences. The move is seen as an attempt to expose the regime's propaganda efforts and show Kim Jong Un as a human being rather than a god-like figure. Local residents near the border have been trying to stop the launches, fearing retaliation from Pyongyang. The defector claims that the goal is to bring attention to the issue and potentially harm the regime, while avoiding direct confrontation.

A new thermal protection case called Optimal has been developed to prevent phone overheating, which can damage devices. The case features built-in temperature sensors that monitor the phone's temperature and automatically activate cooling mechanisms when it exceeds a certain threshold. These mechanisms include using resistance coils to warm up the phone in extremely cold temperatures and micro-fans to cool it down in high temperatures. The case also includes a backup battery option and allows users to customize settings such as temperature zones and alarm thresholds.

A Russian fishing vessel called the Dalniy Vostok freezer trawler went down in the Sea of Okhotsk after colliding with an obstacle, resulting in the deaths of at least 54 people. The incident occurred when the trawler was carrying 132 people, mostly Russians, who were on their way to deliver frozen seafood to markets. Over 60 people were rescued by more than 20 fishing vessels, but 15 remain missing. The cause of the sinking is believed to be a collision with an obstacle, while the trawler itself appears to have keeled over due to hauling too much weight onto its deck.

The article reviews ten food-related apps available for download, highlighting their features and benefits. These apps cater to various needs, such as meal planning, recipe creation, and tracking food waste. Some notable mentions include Chefs Eat, Love Food Hate Waste, and Jamie Oliver's Recipes, offering expert advice and guidance on cooking and nutrition. Additionally, apps like Berry's Wine List provide detailed information on wine selection and pairing, while others focus on managing food budgets and creating personalized meal plans.

Jeremy Clarkson, 53, has taken a break from his Top Gear duties after being dropped from the show due to a "fracas" involving a Top Gear producer. His estranged wife Frances Clarkson, 53, recently took a family vacation to Barbados, where she posted photos of herself relaxing on the beach in a white bikini. The couple had been living apart since 2014, despite previously sharing a daughter and son. Frances accessorized her look with a Help For Heroes wristband and a butterfly clip, while Jeremy Clarkson enjoyed a dip in the sea, reportedly deep in thought.

Aldi, a discount supermarket chain, faced criticism for failing to notify customers of a 0.5% credit card surcharge six months after promising to do so. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) investigated and found that Aldi did not comply with regulations requiring disclosure of such charges. Many Aldi stores still lack clear signage indicating the presence of the surcharge, despite having it in place. This has led to confusion among customers who may unknowingly incur additional fees when using their tap-and-go payment systems.

A group of Russian bullion, valued at millions of pounds, was lost in the River Clyde due to a wartime blunder involving the former Irish Sea ferry-turned-battle-cruiser HMS Ulster Queen. The bullion was loaded onto the ferry in Murmansk in 1942 and was intended to be used to arm Russia. However, the shipment was lost overboard while being transferred to a waiting boat, and the exact circumstances remain unclear. A secret diary kept by the Ulster Queen's engineer, Leonard H. Thomas, provides a detailed account of the events leading up to the disaster.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguayan soccer player, admitted to biting Italy defender Giorgio Chiellini during a World Cup match in Brazil, which led to a four-month ban. His wife Sofia confirmed this after they were alone together, with Suarez initially denying any wrongdoing. However, he eventually confessed to the incident 10 days later when contacted by his phone. Since his release from the ban, Suarez has played well for Barcelona, forming a strong partnership with Lionel Messi and Neymar.

A 48-year-old man named Ranulfo Perez was arrested in New York's Times Square for allegedly groping a 16-year-old girl who was dressed as Elmo. Perez was arrested after he was identified as the suspect by police, despite initially claiming he was mistaken. The incident occurred on Sunday evening, and Perez was released on Tuesday morning due to concerns that the teenager may not have recognized him. Perez was charged with forcible touching in a manner injurious to a child and second-degree harassment. This is the latest in a series of incidents involving costumed characters in Times Square, which have led to increased calls for regulation and licensing fees.

A gunfight erupted between two brothers, Marc Wabafiyebazu and Joshua Wright, in Miami, resulting in the deaths of both brothers. The incident occurred during a drug deal gone wrong, with the two brothers attempting to rob a group of Miami drug dealers. Marc Wabafiyebazu was arrested for felony murder and robbery, while Joshua Wright was fatally shot. His mother, Roxanne Dubé, was also injured in the shooting.

Dr Omar Saadi Al-Atraqchi, a 42-year-old urology specialist, was found guilty of secretly filming men in gym showers while working at Custom House Surgery in North London. He cut holes in Lynx shampoo bottles to conceal iPhones and hid them in the bottles to film men using the showers. Al-Atraqchi pleaded guilty to four counts of voyeurism and was fined £500, ordered to pay £85 costs, and a £25 victim surcharge. He faces a hearing to determine whether he will be struck off the medical register due to his actions.

A former US Army enlistee, John T. Booker Jr., was arrested and charged with attempting to detonate a car bomb at Fort Riley military base in Kansas. Booker, who had expressed admiration for ISIS leader Maj. Nidal Hasan, planned to detonate a vehicle bomb using inert explosives, which he believed would harm American soldiers. Booker enlisted in the Army in 2014 and was scheduled to ship out to basic training in April 2014. However, he was arrested after being questioned by the FBI about his online posts and interactions with a confidential informant. Booker was charged with multiple felonies related to the plot, including attempting to use a weapon of mass destruction and providing material support to ISIS.

A new study suggests that experiencing stressful events, particularly in childhood, can significantly increase the risk of developing type 1 diabetes. The research analyzed data from over 10,000 families and found that 58 children who experienced stressful events, such as a death or illness in the family, divorce, or separation, were three times more likely to develop the condition. This increased risk is attributed to the potential damage caused by these events on the body's immune system, specifically the production of beta cells in the pancreas that produce insulin. The study also highlights genetic predisposition as the primary factor contributing to the development of type 1 diabetes.

A 15-year-old African American teenager, Jamar Nicholson, was shot by a police officer in South Los Angeles after being mistaken for carrying a real gun. He and his friend Jason Huerta were caught by two officers with a toy gun, which turned out to be fake, prompting the officers to shoot both men. Nicholson suffered serious injuries and is now suing the city of Los Angeles for $20 million, claiming he feels traumatized by the experience. Officers initially claimed they shot the men first, but Nicholson's lawyer disputes this, saying the officers fired without justification.

A man lay asleep on the baggage reclaim conveyor belt at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport, causing concern among passengers who were waiting to claim their luggage. Other passengers were more interested in watching him sleep than checking in. The man eventually got up and walked off the belt, but officials decided to release footage of the incident as a warning about the dangers of doing the same thing again. Passengers laughed at the sight of the sleeping man, while airport staff took photos of him before releasing them online.

Cadbury has released a new super bar called the Dairy Milk Spectacular 7, featuring seven rows of unique flavors. This limited-edition bar contains seven different fillings, including Dairy Milk Caramel, Dairy Milk Whole Nut, Dairy Milk Oreo, Dairy Milk Daim, and Dairy Milk Turkish. The bar was created by combining research with food artist Prudence Staite to encourage customers to try new flavors. The seven-row bar is part of a larger effort by Cadbury to celebrate the company's rich history and promote customer engagement.

President Muhammadu Buhari, a 72-year-old former military leader, won Nigeria's presidential election, marking a significant shift towards a more mature and anti-corruption-oriented approach to governance. His campaign promises, including tackling corruption and addressing poverty, resonated with ordinary Nigerians who felt disillusioned with the previous government's handling of these issues. Buhari's victory is seen as a victory for the poor, who have suffered under decades of corruption and mismanagement, particularly in Abuja, where the wealthy elite control vast resources. The election marks a turning point in Nigeria's history, as the country transitions from a corrupt and ineffective regime to one that prioritizes the needs of its citizens.

Daniel O'Reilly, a former British comedian known for his provocative humor, has traveled from London to Sydney via Dubai and Melbourne, documenting his journey in a series of videos. He adopted his "laddish alter ego" character, Dapper Laughs, and mocked air stewards and cleaners during his trip. A petition calling for his TV show "Dapper Laughs: On The Pull" to be canceled due to its sexist content gained over 60,000 signatures. The show was ultimately canceled by ITV, but O'Reilly has since revived his character and announced plans for a new TV sitcom.

A British Muslim family, including Councillor Shakil Ahmed's son Waheed, was caught trying to cross into Syria from Turkey. They were among nine individuals who attempted to enter the country, including Waheed, who is believed to have acted as an Islamic State smuggler. The family, including Waheed's cousin and four children, were apprehended by Turkish authorities and are expected to return to the UK. This incident highlights the ongoing issue of British Muslims attempting to flee to join extremist groups such as ISIS.

Lyme disease, caused by a tick bite, has left Avril Lavigne bedridden for months due to its debilitating symptoms, which include extreme fatigue, joint pain, and memory loss. The singer revealed that she contracted the disease after being bitten by a tick during a trip to Asia and South America. A doctor initially dismissed her concerns, suggesting it might be exhaustion or dehydration, before eventually diagnosing her with Lyme disease. The disease is usually transmitted through a tick bite within 36 hours, and if left untreated, can persist for years.

In August 2013, a fire broke out at the Virgin Mary Church in the Giza province village of Kafr Hakim, Egypt, resulting in the destruction of the building and looting. A total of 71 people were sentenced to life in prison for their involvement in the incident, while others received lesser punishments such as fines and imprisonment. The attack was part of a wave of violence targeting Christian churches and businesses in Egypt, with several other churches and homes also being attacked. The victims include members of the Coptic Christian community, who have long been subject to persecution under Islamic extremist groups.

Two 18-year-old men, Sevdet Besim and two others, aged 19, have been charged with conspiring to carry out an ISIS-inspired terror plot in Australia. The suspects planned to target a major national commemoration event, including a ceremony honoring the soldiers who died in the Gallipoli Campaign in World War I. Authorities believe they intended to carry out attacks against police officers. Sevdet Besim was charged with conspiring to commit terrorist acts, while the other two men were accused of conspiring to do so.

Carles N'Zogbia wore a flamboyant outfit to Aston Villa training, which included a gilet and sunglasses, prompting criticism from Tim Sherwood, who described it as the "worst ever". This comes after N'Zogbia joined the club in February. N'Zogbia has been a regular fixture under Sherwood, known for his flair for style. Sherwood also famously wore a gilet during his tenure as Tottenham manager. The incident occurred during a training session at Villa's Bodymoor Heath complex.

The British photographer Laura Stevens created the "Another November" photo series, capturing the stages of grief following a breakup through intimate and emotionally charged photographs. The series features women posing in various settings, including a foetal position, a bath, and a kitchen, to convey the pain, confusion, and loneliness that follow a lost love. Each photograph is titled after the first name of the woman posing, creating a sense of intimacy and connection between the subjects. Through her work, Stevens aims to process her own experiences of heartbreak and explore the complexities of human emotions.

Andy Murray, the British tennis player, had a nerve-wracking wedding rehearsal before marrying his fiancée Kim Sears in Dunblane Cathedral. The couple met at the 2005 US Open and got engaged last year, and they tied the knot in a private ceremony. Kim Sears left the cathedral earlier than expected, while Andy Murray looked nervously at the proceedings. The newlyweds will celebrate their union in front of friends and family, with homemade bunting and decorations adorning the streets of Dunblane.

A female Pennsylvania police officer, Lisa Mearkle, is facing charges of murder and felony first-degree murder for fatally shooting an unarmed man, David Kassick, twice in the back while he was lying face down on the ground. The incident occurred on February 2, and footage of the shooting shows Mearkle using a stun gun to shoot two bullets into Kassick's back. Mearkle claims she shot Kassick in self-defense, but prosecutors argue that the video evidence supports the prosecution's theory of murder. The case is ongoing, with a preliminary hearing set for Monday and a motion to release the video denied by the court.

Mick Schumacher, the 16-year-old son of seven-time Formula 1 World Champion Michael Schumacher, made his Formula 4 debut at the Oschersleben circuit in Germany. He suffered an accidental 100mph crash while testing his car, but walked away uninjured. Mick Schumacher is seeking to follow in his father's footsteps in the racing world. The 16-year-old finished second in the previous year's Formula 4 championships.

Bruce Jenner, a 65-year-old Olympic gold medalist, is preparing to undergo a sex reassignment surgery as part of his journey towards transitioning into a woman. His family, including his sons Burt, Brandon, and Brody, are reportedly worried about the potential impact of his upcoming docu-series on his reputation and relationships. The eight-part series, set to premiere on E!, aims to educate and raise awareness about Bruce's transition, with his stepdaughter Kim Kardashian expressing support for his decision. Despite concerns from some members of his family, Bruce believes his family is supportive and wants to use his platform to promote acceptance and understanding.

The RSPCA is considering abandoning its policy of pursuing pointless fox hunting prosecutions after dropping a high-profile case involving William Bryer, a joint master of the renowned Cattistock Hunt in Dorset. The charity had previously spent £22.5 million pursuing prosecutions under the Hunting Act, but has since reviewed its approach and will consider leaving the decision to the police and Crown Prosecution Service. The RSPCA's decision comes amid criticism that many of those prosecuted under the Hunting Act are actually involved in "trail hunting" - where dogs follow the scent of a fox without harming it. The organization's policy shift reflects concerns about the effectiveness and ethics of pursuing such cases.

A former police officer turned human lie detector, Darren Stanton, claims that liars often stare, contrary to the traditional notion that they cannot meet eye contact. Stanton, who works as a full-time human lie detector, uses various techniques such as micro-expression training and neuro linguistic programming to detect deception. His expertise has been showcased on TV shows, including ITV's This Morning, where he caught several individuals fibbing, including Philip Schofield and Amanda Holden. Stanton emphasizes that liars often exhibit certain physical cues, such as twitching, blinking, and facial expressions, which can indicate dishonesty.

The author discusses the significance of Easter, a Christian holiday that marks the culmination of Holy Week, which includes Good Friday, Holy Saturday, and Easter Sunday. These three days represent a journey through the human experience, from darkness and suffering to hope and transformation. The author notes that Easter is not just a celebration of Jesus' resurrection but also a reminder of the universal human experience of suffering and mortality. The Triduum, a term referring to the three days of Easter, symbolizes the cyclical nature of life and death, while the Easter weekend represents the promise of renewal and rebirth. Ultimately, the author argues that the Easter Triduum serves as a powerful reminder to move through darkness into light, embracing the complexities and mysteries of the human condition.

A new app called Camoji allows users to create and share animated GIFs on Facebook Messenger, making it easy to capture and share moments with others. The app uses the Messenger service, which has over 600 million users, and integrates with popular platforms like Instagram and WhatsApp. Camoji lets users create GIFs with unique filters and text, and share them instantly via Messenger. The app aims to revolutionize the way people interact with each other through messaging, offering a new way to express oneself. With the introduction of Camoji, Facebook is transforming its messaging service into a more interactive and creative tool.

Labour leader Ed Miliband proposed measures to address immigration, including requiring migrants to learn English and using a shared language to foster community cohesion. He acknowledged that his party had previously been "too timid" on this issue, but emphasized the importance of speaking English in public-facing roles. Conservative immigration minister James Brokenshire dismissed Miliband's proposals, stating that Labour's approach would lead to increased immigration. Miliband's comments sparked criticism, with some arguing that his stance would drive low-skilled migration and exploit migrant workers.

A group of four terrified puppies were rescued after being strapped in a cage to the roof of a van on the freeway in Ohio. The incident occurred during a 300-mile journey from Nova, Ohio to Pennsylvania, where the driver, Wendell Steiner, was stopped by police due to concerns about animal welfare. Steiner claimed that the puppies belonged to his father, but the police found no evidence of this, instead discovering that the puppies were actually being transported to be adopted. The puppies were taken to a local veterinarian hospital for examination and will be placed with the Human Society of Great Akron for adoption.

British gymnast Louis Smith will represent Great Britain for the first time since his double Olympic medal-winning performance at London 2012. He was chosen from a strong field of competitors, including reigning pommel horse champion Max Whitlock and Olympic team-mates Kristian Thomas, Sam Oldham, and Daniel Purvis. This marks Smith's return to international competition after a four-year hiatus. The European Championships take place in Montpellier between April 15 and 19, featuring individual all-around and apparatus events.

Mohammed Dahbi, a New York taxi driver, was ordered to pay $10,000 in damages to a lesbian couple after he discriminated against them by telling them to stop kissing in the back of his cab. The incident occurred on September 18, 2011, when Dahbi ordered the couple to keep their behavior "for the bedroom" due to their sexual orientation. The couple, Kassie Thornton and Christy Spitzer, reported the incident to the Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings, who found in favor of the couple, awarding them $10,000 in damages. Dahbi was also required to attend anti-discrimination training and pay a $5,000 civil penalty to the city.

Jonas Gutierrez, a 31-year-old midfielder, was dropped from Newcastle's starting lineup after a heated argument with head coach John Carver. The incident occurred during a match against Tottenham, where Gutierrez tweeted that he was "tired" and felt "trapped". Carver responded by saying that Gutierrez was being treated poorly and wanted to leave the club. Despite being released by the team, Gutierrez will remain in the squad for Saturday's match against Swansea, with Carver and the player seeking to move on from their dispute. This comes after a seven-year tenure at Newcastle, during which Gutierrez played a key role in the team's success.

ISIS militants infiltrated the Palestinian-run Yarmouk refugee camp in Damascus, killing a blindfolded and bound couple in a gruesome display of violence. The militants, affiliated with Al Qaeda, used stones to kill the couple, who were accused of "fornication" despite being innocent. This marked the latest escalation of ISIS's brutal tactics in Syria, following clashes with government forces in the area. The incident occurred just days after Jordan closed its border with Syria due to clashes between rebels and government forces.

Amanda Peake Glover, a devoted mother of four, died suddenly after collapsing during the Palmetto Half Marathon in South Carolina. She was a fitness enthusiast and had recently completed the Myrtle Beach Marathon with her brother. Her friend Ashley Blocker described her as a "devoted" mother who would often cross the finish line with her husband Benji. The cause of her death remains unclear, but it appears to have been related to the physical exertion.

Labour's shadow chancellor, Ed Balls, was left briefly stumped by a basic maths question during a speech in Leeds, revealing that he relies on his mother-in-law for help with maths. The question was about the answer to seven times six, which he answered correctly despite looking down at his feet. This came after he admitted that he often seeks advice from his wife's maths expertise. The incident occurred during a Q&A session on Good Morning Britain, where he also discussed his own struggles with maths.

English cricketer Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott have formed a record-breaking partnership of 10 times, joining Hobbs and Sutcliffe as the fifth duo to achieve this feat. This milestone marks a significant achievement for both players, who have also had notable partnerships with other teammates such as Strauss, Pietersen, and Bell. Meanwhile, West Indies' Shannon Gabriel continues his impressive form, keeping England's batsmen on their toes with his blistering speed. In addition, England captain Alastair Cook and former captain Jonathan Trott recently shook hands after reaching their 10th century partnership.

New York City skin clinic Skin Laundry offers a popular laser facial treatment that promises to tighten skin and improve complexion. The treatment involves a two-step process, where a nurse applies gel and then a pulsed light to cleanse and treat the skin. Clients must sign a waiver releasing their personal information to a funeral director and coroner, but claim that the risk of serious side effects is low. Despite concerns, the clinic has gained popularity among clients, with many reporting improvements in their skin after multiple sessions.

Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao's highly anticipated boxing match has seen its tickets sell out quickly, with over 10,000 tickets available for the event. The MGM property box offices saw a surge in demand for the fight, which took place just two days ago. Tickets for the weigh-in, where both fighters will meet for the first time since their respective weight classes, have been sold out in minutes. The most expensive tickets, costing up to $7,500, can only be purchased through specific websites like Ticketmaster or mgmgrand.com.

Victoria's Secret Angel Alessandra Ambrosio, 34, is recovering at UCLA Hospital in Los Angeles after undergoing a medical procedure for constant headaches. She was spotted partying at the Coachella festival in California with her fiancé Jamie Mazur, where she posted about it on social media. Ambrosio suffered from constant headaches during the event, which led to her seeking medical attention. She is currently receiving treatment at the Ronald Reagan Medical Center.

A rowing team from Oxford University Women's Boat Race faced rescue efforts by the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) after being swept away by strong winds and waves while training on the Thames River. The team, consisting of women, were attempting to prepare for the upcoming Boat Race, which takes place on April 11. The RNLI provided assistance, recovering the sunken boat and returning it to Oxford's base. The incident occurred during a training session, highlighting the importance of preparedness and teamwork in emergency situations. The RNLI has a long history of saving lives on the Thames, with over 3,600 rescues since its inception in 2002.

Lionel Messi has been lauded by Paris Saint-Germain playmaker Lucas Moura as one of the greatest players in the world, praising his exceptional skill and technique. Moura has expressed admiration for Messi's ability to dominate games, citing him as an inspiration. The two South Americans have a long-standing rivalry, but Moura sees Messi as the best player in the world, stating that he is the top choice among Brazilian and Argentine footballers. This sentiment reflects the intense competition between the two nations, which adds to the excitement of their upcoming Champions League encounter. As part of PSG, Moura knows that facing Messi will be a challenging task, but he remains optimistic about the outcome.

A 20-year-old Polish teenager named Gena Turgel, who weighed only 20 pounds, met a British soldier, Sergeant Norman Turgel, during the liberation of Bergen-Belsen concentration camp in 1945. A recent study suggests that the Earth may have collided with a body similar to the planet Mercury, potentially explaining the presence of a hot core and unusual elemental ratios in the planet's mantle. The collision, which occurred around 4.5 billion years ago, would have generated heat and driven the formation of Earth's core and moon. Researchers propose that a Mars-sized body, possibly composed of sulfur-rich material, struck the young Earth, producing radioactive elements that fueled the planet's core. This theory challenges the traditional understanding of Earth's formation and raises questions about how the planet ended up in its current oxidized state.

Daniel Ricciardo practiced with a martial artist at Guyi Garden ahead of the upcoming Chinese Grand Prix, seeking to improve his stance and prepare for the challenges ahead. A drone carrying small traces of radioactive material landed on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's office in Tokyo, sparking concerns about nuclear safety. Manchester City fans were ejected from Old Trafford for allegedly mocking the Munich Air Disaster during a 4-2 derby defeat to Manchester United. A 28-year-old heavily pregnant Jehovah's Witness, Jenny-Lee, refused a blood transfusion during childbirth despite medical advice, resulting in the death of her unborn baby, Aroura. A Muslim father, Mohammad Liaqat, launched a racist tirade against Xavier Bowers, the headteacher of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic High School in Accrington, after two teenage pupils were banned from attending due to their refusal to shave their beards. A volcano in Chile called Calbuco erupted suddenly, forcing 1,500 people to flee their homes due to a massive ash cloud and lava plume. Prime Minister David Cameron defended the Church of England against accusations of dismissing welfare policies as immoral, saying the church's values of compassion, forgiveness, kindness, hard work, and responsibility are essential to the nation. A 33-year-old airport worker, Brandon Afoa, was awarded $40 million in compensation after a freak runway accident left him paralyzed from the waist down. A survey conducted by Frontline Spot On found that the "perfect" dog would be a crossbreed combining characteristics from various breeds, such as an English bulldog, King Charles spaniel, and Irish setter. Scottish soldiers, Jason Collins, 22, and Shaun Smith, 25, were convicted of kicking and punching a civilian, James Wormald, 25, in a drunken attack near Catterick Garrison in North Yorkshire. A 18-month-old boy and his sister drowned while trying to fend off a bee on a canal in Yuma, Arizona, after their mother attempted to escape with their stroller. The stroller rolled into the canal, and despite efforts to retrieve it, it was swept away by strong currents. Terry McCarty, a 29-year-old former firefighter from Hawthorne, Nevada, survived a childhood accident that left him with 70% of his body severely burned in a fire that occurred when his brothers filled a bowl with kerosene and accidentally knocked it on him. Veteran Robert Clark, a Second World War survivor, has raised £10,000 in just four days to help him remain in his own home due to a London council's refusal to provide a live-in carer. Overall, the report highlights the increasing presence of women in leadership roles worldwide.

Australian teenager Violeta Tupuola joins the viral #kyliejennerchallenge by using a shot glass to suck up air in her mouth, causing her lips to become visibly protruded and resembling a duck. The unusual method, inspired by Kylie Jenner's famous pout, has sparked widespread attention online, with many comparing her to a duck due to the dramatic change in appearance. Violeta initially found the experience painful and disconcerting, but later expressed surprise and amusement at the reaction. The trend, which encourages users to experiment with blowing up their lips using various objects, has been met with criticism and ridicule from some, labeling it "dumb" and "gross".

Stuart McCall, the Ibrox manager, urged Rangers to respond immediately to their second Championship defeat of the season, despite being down 2-0 at halftime against Queen of the South. McCall remained defiant, stating that the team will bounce back stronger on Sunday against Raith Rovers. Rangers remain third in the table, while Queen of the South jumped to fourth place due to their impressive performance. McCall praised his team's resilience, saying they showed signs of improvement in the first half before ultimately losing. He also commended striker Derek Lyle for scoring the opening goal, which sparked jubilation among the fans.

A horse named Charly was vandalized by a tagger with the signature "RBS" while patrolling Venice Beach. The tagger used silver spray paint to mark the horse's flank, causing some damage. Authorities are seeking the identity of the person responsible through the "RBS" tag itself. Witnesses reported that the paint came off easily, suggesting that the tagger may have been careless or inexperienced. The LAPD is asking the public for help in identifying the culprit.

Queens Park Rangers secured a 3-3 draw against Aston Villa at Villa Park, despite trailing 2-1 at halftime. The match ended in a stalemate, with both teams creating chances but neither able to find the winning goal. Rangers' chairman Tony Fernandes watched the game from his iPhone, describing his emotions as "despair" and "pride". Clint Hill scored a crucial goal for QPR, while Chris Ramsey praised the team's fighting spirit. The draw keeps QPR in the relegation zone, but they move up to 18th place with six points.

Here is a short summary:

Tottenham's Harry Kane topped the EA Sports' Performance Index this week, scoring his 30th goal of the season in a 3-1 win over Newcastle United. He achieved a Game Index score of 55.1, making him the Premier League's best player. Kane's teammate Christian Erisken scored a goal in the win, while Eden Hazard scored the winner against Manchester United. Kane is also the year nominee for the PFA Player of the Year award. Meanwhile, Southampton midfielder Morgan Schneiderlin finished fourth in the rankings with a score of 35.3.

A father in Australia created a humorous t-shirt for his daughter warning other boys to stay clear of her, which quickly went viral after being shared online. The image features a muscular man wearing a shirt with the phrase "Stay Clear Boys" emblazoned across it, accompanied by a cheeky grin. The post gained over 370,000 likes and 45,000 shares within hours of its initial posting. Many commented on the absurdity of the situation, with some jokingly suggesting alternative solutions such as a "Dad Security" or "Boys Stay Away" sign.

A New York woman's body was found hanging from a fire escape in her apartment building on Sunday morning. She was identified as a 66-year-old woman with mental health issues, but witnesses reported that she appeared to be alive when seen by neighbors. A neighbor claimed that she initially thought the body was a "Halloween prank" before realizing it was real. The incident occurred on Sunday afternoon, and authorities confirmed that the woman was left dangling for over an hour before being rescued.

Celtic's actions in the Scottish Cup semi-final against Inverness Caledonian Thistle have sparked widespread criticism, with the club's decision to write to the Scottish Football Association (SFA) over a disputed penalty call appearing to be a desperate attempt to salvage their reputation. The incident has highlighted concerns about the state of Scottish football, with many questioning whether the country's top clubs are prioritizing image over performance. Celtic's captain Scott Brown has also spoken out, criticizing the club's behavior, while striker Leigh Griffiths expressed disappointment and frustration. Meanwhile, Inverness Caledonian Thistle's victory over Celtic has raised questions about the standard of Scottish football, with many calling for a re-evaluation of the country's governing body.

Real Madrid won the Champions League final against Atletico Madrid in Lisbon one year ago, but since then, they have drawn six of their last seven matches against their city rivals. This includes a 2-2 draw in the Champions League quarter-final second leg last week. Real Madrid scored two goals in that match, while Atletico Madrid scored none. Atletico Madrid has had success against Real Madrid in recent times, having won four of their last five meetings. On Wednesday night's Champions League quarter-final second leg, Atletico Madrid defeated Real Madrid 2-1, with Fernando Torres scoring twice.

Ile Louët, a 19th-century lighthouse in Brittany, France, offers a unique and secluded retreat for up to 10 guests. This picturesque island features stunning ocean views, a quaint cottage, and a lighthouse keeper's cottage, making it an ideal destination for adventurous travelers. The cost for a 2-night stay ranges from €200 to €145, depending on the season, and includes access to the island via ferry or private transportation. With its remote location and limited amenities, Ile Louët is a perfect retreat for those seeking a tranquil escape amidst nature.

A 26-year-old man named Boobesh Palani, from India, was rescued from Wellington Harbour by two brave teenage girls, Kelly McKay and Payge Olds, after he was pulled from the water by a fisherman. The man's identity was identified through a post on social media, and his family expressed gratitude for the police's efforts to locate him. The incident occurred on Monday night, and the man's cries for help were heard by a fisherman who alerted the group, leading to the rescue. The two girls' bravery and quick thinking saved the man's life, and they received praise from senior Sergeant Andre Kowalczyk of New Zealand Police for their heroic actions.

Scientists have developed a new material that can generate hydrogen from water, making it a cleaner alternative to traditional methods of producing hydrogen. This breakthrough involves a patented catalyst that improves the efficiency of the water electrolysis process, allowing for the creation of storable hydrogen fuel. The catalyst can be applied to various electrode surfaces, enabling direct and economical production. This innovation could revolutionize the production of clean hydrogen power, reducing reliance on fossil fuels and increasing storage capacity.

Labour leader Ed Miliband made his first campaign appearance in three days after taking a break over the Easter weekend. He campaigned in Bristol, where he addressed a crowd and launched a fresh attack on the Conservative record on the NHS. Meanwhile, Prime Minister David Cameron embarked on a whirlwind tour of the UK, meeting with supporters in various locations across the country. The Labour leader's appearance came ahead of a potential showdown with the Conservatives in the upcoming 'Challengers Debate', which will feature the Prime Minister and other opposition leaders.

Saudi Arabia launched airstrikes targeting a school in Yemen, hitting a nearby military base, injuring several students. The strikes occurred after Yemeni officials reported that Saudi airstrikes targeted a school in Ibb province, killing at least six students. The airstrikes were part of a larger conflict in Yemen, where the Houthis have been fighting for control of the country. The US has provided support to Saudi Arabia in its efforts to combat the Houthis, including providing weapons supplies and sharing intelligence.

A 38-year-old woman, Julieane Jablonski, was charged with providing marijuana to a minor and felony tampering with a witness in connection to a case involving her 19-year-old son, Austin Essig, who jumped out of a third-story window while under the influence of a marijuana-laced brownie. Essig had consumed the brownie without disclosing its contents to authorities, leading to his hospitalization. The incident occurred in Fort Collins, Colorado, where marijuana is legal for recreational use but not for minors. Jablonski was booked on suspicion of both charges. An investigation found that the marijuana levels in the brownie were extremely high, which critics argue could cause harm to individuals who are not regular users.

Liverpool forward Divock Origi has expressed enthusiasm for joining the club after witnessing the progress of its young players, particularly winger Jordan Ibe, and winger Raheem Sterling. He credits the support of the fans for boosting his morale and motivation. Origi joined Liverpool from Lille after impressing for Belgium at the 2014 World Cup. This season has been challenging for him, balancing league and European competition, but he believes it has strengthened him. Origi hopes to bring a similar level of improvement to Liverpool, where he will be working under manager Brendan Rodgers.

ESPN sports reporter Britt McHenry was suspended for one week after being caught on camera verbally attacking an Advanced Towing employee, Gina Michelle, in a parking lot in Arlington, Virginia. McHenry apologized for her actions, stating she let her emotions get the best of her and used derogatory language. The video of the incident sparked outrage, leading to a petition calling for her firing from her role in Washington, D.C. McHenry's supporters defended her, claiming she was simply expressing herself and defending women's rights, while critics argue that her behavior is sexist and body-shaming.

A Scottish illustrator named Johanna Basford has created two bestselling coloring books, "Secret Garden" and "Enchanted Forest", which appeal to adults who want to relax and express themselves creatively through coloring. These books have sold over 1.4 million copies worldwide, outperforming traditional cookbooks and even rivaling the sales of adult-oriented titles. The trend began in France, where coloring was seen as a therapeutic activity, and has since spread globally, with many adults seeking to escape the stresses of modern life through this calming activity. Experts attribute the trend to the desire for human connection and creativity, as well as a resistance to modern technology.

A study by the NHS found that the organization handed out 404,500 prescriptions for suncream and 4.7 million for indigestion pills in 2014, totaling £13 million and £29 million respectively. This comes despite concerns about the system's efficiency and fairness. Patients are being prescribed unnecessary items like toothpaste, Calpol, and Vaseline, leading critics to call for greater flexibility in prescribing decisions. The issue highlights the challenges faced by the NHS during times of financial strain, particularly when it comes to managing demand for essential medications.

Pilots like flying Boeing 747s due to their spacious cabins and comfortable seating. Mark Vanhoenacker's book explores the joys and challenges of being a pilot, drawing from his own experiences as a senior first officer with British Airways. The book delves into the unique aspects of flying 747s, such as the "frozen surface" of the Arctic Ocean and the importance of measuring countries in jet time. A troubled co-pilot named Andreas Lubitz caused the crash of Germanwings Flight 9525, leading to increased scrutiny of pilots' mental health and airline vetting procedures.

Manchester City manager Alan Pardew has stated that despite Chelsea's current lead in the Barclays Premier League title race, he remains confident that his team can still catch up and claim the title. The Eagles' manager has ruled out the possibility of Manchester City coming back from behind to win the title, citing their strong position in the league. In fact, Pardew believes that even if City were to lose this match, they would still be able to secure the title due to their superior goal difference. This comes after Manchester City's historic 1-0 victory over Liverpool in the 2012 Premier League title race. With Chelsea holding a six-point lead, Pardew's message to his team is one of confidence and determination.

Michael Carrick, a 33-year-old Manchester United midfielder, has expressed his desire to pursue a career in motorsport, particularly Formula One, after enjoying a successful season with the team. He credits his experience playing for Manchester United, which included celebrating a goal against Liverpool, for helping shape him into the person he is today. Carrick plans to continue balancing his football career with other interests, such as fitness and nutrition, to ensure he remains healthy and active well into his 40s. With 34 years old, Carrick feels ready to hang up his boots and explore new passions outside of football.

A Wood Green animal charity is partnering with Handy to offer a cat fostering service to help homeowners rid their homes of mice infestations. The charity has partnered with Handy to provide a cat fostering service, where customers can lend a cat to help deter mice. The cats are trained to use their scent to scare away unwanted rodents, and the charity claims that the cats can effectively chase away mice without harming them. The service is available in London, with over 200 cats currently in need of a home, and aims to provide a humane alternative to traditional pest control methods.

The Coachella festival saw a range of unusual and outrageous outfits from celebrities, with many choosing bold and daring ensembles. This year's event featured a variety of bright colors, patterns, and accessories, including neon lights, flowers, and elaborate headgear. Reality star Kylie Jenner and singer Katy Perry stood out with their vibrant and eclectic styles, while others opted for more subdued looks. Despite the overall sense of excess, some attendees chose to keep things simple, such as a plain white dress and a minimalist approach to accessorizing.

The Sandringham museum at the Norfolk estate has undergone significant changes after being closed for a winter period. The updated display features around 62 items, including stuffed animals, skins, and tusks, which were removed from public display and stored in storage. The museum makes a pointed reference to the end of the "destructive era" of hunting and collecting endangered species, such as rhinos and elephants. The removal of the items raises questions about the legality of certain pieces, including ivory and skins, under European Council regulations.

. £13.50, Waitrose. Finally, if you want to splurge, this one is worth considering. Richer, more complex, and with a slightly more pronounced acidity, it’s perfect for sipping on its own or pairing with food.

So, how do you decide which one to choose? Here are some tips:

* Look for the DOC label – it guarantees a certain level of quality.
* Check the ABV – look for a lower ABV (around 11%) for a lighter, fresher taste.
* Choose a Prosecco that suits your taste preferences – some are sweeter, while others are drier.
* Consider the price – generally, the higher the price, the better the quality.
* Don’t be afraid to try new things – you never know what you might discover!

And remember, the best prosecco is always the one that makes you happy!

A former Adelaide doctor, Tareq Kamleh, who fled to join the Islamic State, is still practicing medicine in Australia despite appearing in a propaganda video encouraging foreign medics to join the terrorist organization. He features in a recent ISIS recruitment video, which has sparked outrage among his former colleagues, who describe him as "immoral" and "sexually manipulative". Kamleh completed his medical degree at Adelaide University and worked at several hospitals before leaving Australia on a flight to Kuala Lumpur last month. His actions have raised concerns about the potential risks of allowing individuals with extremist views to continue practicing medicine in Australia.

A devastating car crash occurred on Wyee Road near Doyalson in NSW Central Coast, resulting in the deaths of two siblings, Piper Kulk, 8, and William Kulk, 9. The incident happened on Saturday evening, with Piper's grandmother, Helen Boddy, driving the car and her husband, Daniel, and their children, Daniel, 12, and Chantelle, 31, also present. The car spun out of control and collided with an ute, causing severe injuries to all occupants. Seven people were involved in the crash, with Piper and William dying shortly after arrival at the hospital. The cause of the crash remains under investigation, but heavy rain was cited as the contributing factor.

Dino Maglio, a former Italian policeman, was convicted of raping an 18-year-old girl via a couch-surfing website. He claimed the sex was consensual, despite admitting to spiking the girl with a tranquilizer and then having sex with her. A year-long investigation revealed that Maglio had used the website to lure underage girls to his home, where he drugged and raped them. The girl, now 16, testified against Maglio, describing how he claimed the sex was consensual but ultimately raped her.

Politicians such as Ed Miliband, Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg, and Green Party leader Natalie Bennett advise against sexting due to its risks. A quiz posed questions about politicians' personal lives, prompting responses suggesting that sexting can be "risky" and "dodgy" for both younger and older individuals. Former politicians like Brooks Newmark and Iain Corby have faced scandals related to sexting, including being caught exchanging explicit messages or engaging in illicit activities. The scandals have raised concerns about the potential consequences of sexting among politicians.

A 48-year-old man, Ian Walters, is accused of murdering his 48-year-old wife, Tracy, after intentionally crashing his car into a tree while driving on the M1 motorway last year. Walters, a former driving test examiner, claimed that his wife's inability to satisfy his sex demands led to the fatal accident. However, prosecutors argue that conflict over sex was a major factor in their troubled marriage. Walters denied the charges, saying he fell asleep at the wheel due to medication. The trial continues, with Walters describing his wife as his "world" and admitting to having fainted twice in the two years leading up to the crash.

A drone sighting near Manchester Airport caused temporary flight suspensions due to concerns over potential collisions with commercial airliners. Flights departed and arrived at the airport were disrupted, with some experiencing delays and others being diverted to other airports. The drone's presence raised fears of a collision, prompting a police helicopter to scour the area. After a thorough search, no evidence of the drone was found, but the situation remains under investigation. Manchester Airport reopened its second runway after the situation was resolved.

Chinese authorities have developed a powerful cyberattack called the "Great Cannon", which uses a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) technique to target servers outside of China, including those of Western news outlets like The New York Times and GitHub. The attack is designed to disrupt traffic to these targets, potentially crippling their ability to function. The Great Cannon is a significant improvement over the traditional Great Firewall, which monitors and blocks internet traffic entering China. The attack is likely aimed at targeting Chinese citizens who seek to access Western news and information, and could be used to silence critics of the Chinese government.

Spain's Ciudad Real airport, located near Madrid, was once a thriving transportation hub serving both Madrid and the coastal region. After closing in 2012 due to financial difficulties, the airport stood vacant until it was sold for £86 million in 2023. The abandoned airport remains idle, despite efforts to revive it with maintenance work still ongoing. The site includes a 4,000-meter-long runway and a 28,000 square foot terminal building, which was once used to accommodate thousands of passengers annually.

Detective Patrick Cherry, a member of the NYPD's Joint Terrorism Task Force, appeared on NBC 4 New York to apologize for his behavior during a traffic stop. He was caught on camera yelling at an Uber driver, Humayun, who responded with insults and hostility. Cherry was subsequently stripped of his badge and gun and placed on administrative duty due to the incident. The NYPD's internal affairs department investigated the matter, and Cherry was transferred to civilian review board. The incident sparked widespread outrage, with many calling for greater accountability within law enforcement.

Edwin van der Sar, a former Manchester United goalkeeper, has expressed his confidence that Louis van Gaal's return as manager will help bring back the "glory days" for the Red Devils. Van Gaal's team, currently sitting second in the Premier League, face Chelsea on Saturday and hopes to gain an advantage in their match. The Blues are likely to be heavy favorites to win the title, but Van Gaal remains optimistic about the possibility of challenging for the championship. With a few key signings planned for the summer, Van Gaal believes the team can improve and potentially bring more success.

Bournemouth drew 2-2 with Sheffield Wednesday despite trailing to a Kieran Lee sucker punch in the 36th minute. The Cherries' Simon Francis was sent off in the 78th minute due to a red card. Bournemouth had 15 penalties taken throughout the season, while Wednesday had none. Callum Wilson felt that he should have received a penalty in the second half, which ultimately led to a late equalizer from Chris Maguire. The match ended in a stalemate, with both teams sharing points.

A 32-year-old man, Carl Garry Chapman, was arrested and charged with various offenses related to an abduction incident involving his 18-year-old ex-partner, Billy-Anne Huxham. Huxham was found alive after being held captive for several days, and her Facebook page was flooded with messages from concerned friends urging her to stay safe. Chapman was subsequently detained and charged with multiple crimes, including unlawful use of a motor vehicle, assault, and deprivation of liberty. Huxham was rescued when her ex-partner contacted her family, who alerted police, and was found in a nearby restaurant, where she had fled to escape her abductor.

Southampton manager Ronald Koeman wants his team to focus on themselves and start scoring goals after struggling to find form in recent weeks. His striker Graziano Pelle continues to struggle in front of goal, but Koeman believes he can turn things around. With a crucial Premier League match against Hull City looming, Koeman is urging his players to improve their performance. To achieve success, Koeman needs his team to regain their scoring touch, which could see them move up the table. This would give them a chance to challenge for European qualification.

A large number of goldfish have invaded Teller Lake in Boulder, Colorado, after being dumped by pet owners. The invasive species threaten the local aquatic ecosystem, including native fish such as channel catfish, blue gill fish, and sunfish. To address the problem, authorities consider removing the fish using electrofishing or draining the lake. The decision comes after a similar incident occurred at Thunderbird Lake in Boulder in 2012, where over 2,275 koi goldfish were removed due to non-native species introduction.

Everton goalkeeper Tim Howard believes the Europa League is not to blame for the team's disappointing performance in the Premier League, despite playing 10 European games. The Toffees' worst season in nine years may be attributed to factors beyond the competition, as they finished 25 points behind their target of finishing in the top 10. Everton's 4-2-3-1 formation and 32-game schedule in the Europa League have taken their toll, according to Howard. The team's struggles extend to their Champions League aspirations, where they were eliminated by Dynamo Kiev in the quarterfinals. With a goal from Jonjo Shelvey equalizing a penalty, Everton's chances of achieving their desired position seem slim.

The Atlanta Hawks defeated the Brooklyn Nets 131-99 on Saturday night, marking their 57th win of the season. Forward Paul Millsap suffered a right shoulder injury in the first half, leaving him out for the remainder of the game. Despite this setback, the Hawks still managed to secure their 57th win of the season with a convincing 131-99 victory. Meanwhile, Al Horford scored 20 points, including a crucial three-pointer in the second half, as the Hawks cruised past the Nets. The Hawks' 66-48 halftime lead remained intact until the end of the game, when they ultimately fell short against the Miami Heat 99-98.

A new study by Ofcom reveals that the average 4G speed in the UK is only 2.5 times faster than 3G, according to the latest data. The study found that 4G speeds range from 10.7Mbit/s to 18.6Mbit/s, with EE's network offering the fastest average speed of 18.6Mbit/s. The results contradict the claims made by mobile phone companies that 4G services would be "five times faster" than 3G. The study's findings suggest that the increased demand for 4G services may be causing slowdowns in the network.

Jimmy Anderson reached 100 Test matches for England, receiving a special silver cap from Mike Atherton. Chris Gayle chose to leave West Indies to play in the Indian Premier League (IPL) instead of representing his country. Meanwhile, West Indies' best batsman Chris Gayle hit 21 runs in a Royal Challengers Bangalore loss. The West Indies Cricket Board president Dave Cameron emphasized the importance of playing for the team over personal gain, while Ian Bell wore a new helmet designed to protect his head after losing Phillip Hughes.

Ellia Beasley, a 22-year-old model from New Milton, Hampshire, got a tattoo of the lyrics "scream your heart out" from the song "Rooftops" by Lost Prophet on her belly in 2012. The tattoo was a deliberate choice made during her teenage years, but she later regretted it after discovering that the band's lead singer, Ian Watkins, was a serial paedophile and child abuser. Watkins was sentenced to 35 years in prison for multiple child sex offenses, including attempting to rape a fan's baby. A tattoo artist, Kevin Paul, helped Ellia come up with a new design to cover the original tattoo, resulting in a giant owl on her stomach.

Taxi driver Uncle Teng, known for taking 30,000 selfies with passengers, has become a local celebrity in Shenyang, North China. He started this unique tipping system ten years ago when picking up tourists in -30C weather conditions. With 58 years old, Uncle Teng captures thousands of selfies with passengers daily, often asking for a quick snap at the end of the ride. His infectious smile has made him a beloved figure in the community, earning him recognition worldwide, including being named one of the top 100 most influential people in China.

A comedian named Vijay Chokal-Ingam, brother of actress Mindy Kaling, revealed in his new book "Almost Black" that he pretended to be an African American to gain admission to medical school. Chokal-Ingam claims he transformed his appearance to meet the admissions requirements, despite being aware that it was a racial act. However, Chokal-Ingam denies denying knowledge of his brother's actions, stating that he was not aware of his brother's plan. Chokal-Ingam's decision to pretend to be black was motivated by a desire to attend the St. Louis University School of Medicine, where he hoped to overcome systemic racism in the admissions process.

A 53-year-old woman named Julie McKenzie visited her doctor due to nagging back pain, initially thinking it was related to scoliosis. After undergoing X-rays, she discovered she had a malignant tumour in her coccyx, a benign tumour, and required surgical removal. Despite initial misdiagnosis, Julie underwent successful surgery and received a prognosis of cure. Now, she continues to deal with chronic pain, but thanks to her decision to seek further evaluation, she is hopeful about her recovery.

A French Bulldog in California became a viral sensation after being left alone in a car while its owner was away. The dog, whose identity remains unknown, continuously honked a horn, causing concern among passersby. A video captured by a witness showed the dog standing firm against the horn, refusing to back down despite attempts to coax it into getting down. The incident sparked outrage, but the dog's owner claimed it was "absolutely spoiled rotten" and had been well-cared for.

Photographer Anthony Barbour, 33, from Liverpool, creates surreal 360-degree photographs by spending hours at unique locations such as Sefton Park, Mudeford Beach, and Durdle Door in various parts of the UK. He captures these scenes through slow rotations, often finding opportunities in unexpected places like open spaces and unchanging landscapes. His process involves shooting with a Canon 1100d DSLR and editing software to stitch and layer the photos together. This creative outlet helps him cope with his recent diagnosis of Ulcerative Pan Colitis.

A 21-year-old son of a Labour councillor, Waheed Ahmed, was arrested at Manchester Airport on suspicion of terrorism offences while attempting to enter Syria with eight of his relatives. He was later released without charge due to lack of evidence. Waheed was deported by Turkish authorities and returned to Britain on a plane with holidaymakers. His father, Labour councillor Shakil Ahmed, denied any involvement in his son's actions, stating he believes Waheed is innocent and would have reported him if he suspected he was in danger.

Carlos Colina, a 32-year-old man from Massachusetts, has been charged with murder after finding human remains in a duffel bag in Cambridge. He had previously faced assault and battery charges related to another incident involving a 26-year-old man named Jonathan Camilien. Authorities discovered the first set of remains on Saturday, which matched those found in a separate case involving Colina. Colina was arrested and faces additional charges, including murder, after being linked to the second set of remains through a surveillance video.

Aaron Murphy scored twice in a seven-try romp as Huddersfield beat Catalans Dragons 38-14 in a Super League match. Murphy, an in-form winger, scored six tries in his last five appearances, including two in the same match. The Huddersfield side secured a crucial win to end a three-match losing run. They dominated the game, scoring seven tries in total, with Murphy's second try coming just 27 minutes into the second half. The match ended with a 27-minute try from Leroy Cudjoe, securing a 38-14 victory for Huddersfield.

Three people poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger at a gas station in South Los Angeles, setting it on fire. A heated argument between the driver and the suspects led to the act, which resulted in the car being engulfed in flames. The suspects attempted to steal the vehicle before pouring more gasoline on it, causing extensive damage to its front end. The incident remains under investigation by the Los Angeles County Fire Department.

Hillary Clinton's Twitter follower count appears to be inflated due to artificial engagement, with many being fake or inactive. Her total follower count is estimated to be around 2 million, but only 44% of these are genuine users, leaving 56% to be fake or inactive. Additionally, a similar analysis of her Facebook page reveals that nearly 46,000 of her fans are from Baghdad, Iraq, despite being labeled as "likes" rather than actual supporters. This raises questions about the authenticity of her online presence.

Andrea Dossena, a 33-year-old former Liverpool player, was arrested on suspicion of shoplifting at Harrods in Knightsbridge. He was charged with shoplifting and released on bail pending further inquiries. Dossena had previously played for Liverpool, scoring a winning goal against Real Madrid in the Champions League. He signed with League One strugglers Leyton Orient in November.

A rescue operation freed nearly 100 dogs trapped in a dark, filthy barn in Manchester, Tennessee, where they had been living in squalor for an unknown period. The dogs, mostly adult breeds, were found to be extremely emaciated and suffered from severe health issues, including acid burns from their own urine and numerous parasites. Authorities have charged the property owner, 64-year-old Caroline Irby, with 10 counts of animal cruelty. The rescue efforts involved over 200 workers and volunteers, who helped assess the dogs and provide medical care, including vaccinations and decompression time.

Michael Easy, 29, from Southampton, Hampshire, was jailed for 15 months after breaching a restraining order and assaulting two prison officers at Winchester Prison. He posed on Facebook in Dame Edna Everage-style sunglasses and a platinum wig, taunting police by posting photographs of himself. His former girlfriend, 19, reported the situation to the police, who then arrested him. Easy was released from prison after serving 15 months, but reoffended by breaching the restraining order and assaulting prison officers. He is currently facing four months in jail for breaching the order and assaulting two prison guards.

A 18-year-old Long Island resident, Harold Ekeh, received acceptance letters from all eight Ivy League colleges, including Harvard, Yale, and several others. This marks a remarkable achievement considering he moved to Long Island 10 years ago. Harold, a straight-A student and editor-in-chief of his student newspaper, attributes his success to his resilient parents, who instilled in him the drive to succeed. Despite receiving multiple acceptance letters, Harold downplays the significance of the achievement, saying it's just "the American Dream."

British Prime Minister David Cameron revealed in an interview that his marriage to his wife Samantha was "falling apart" due to the immense pressure of caring for their son Ivan, who was born with Ohtahara Syndrome, a rare brain disorder requiring constant care and support. Ivan passed away at age six in 2009. The couple's struggles with the demands of raising a disabled child led to a breakdown in their relationship. Their experiences have inspired Samantha to speak out about the challenges faced by families dealing with disabilities, particularly in terms of finding a balance between supporting their loved ones and maintaining their own well-being.

The BBC's iPlayer service has experienced issues with leaving off the last minutes of various radio dramas, causing frustration among listeners who feel it ruins their viewing experience. The problem affects several popular shows, including Dad's Army and Hancock's Half Hour, and is attributed to the system used to record programs. Listeners claim that the delay causes confusion when attempting to watch the final minutes of a program. The BBC has apologized for the inconvenience and plans to add extra time to the end of recorded content to prevent similar issues in the future.

The CNN Student News program discussed various global events, including a California drought affecting residents and businesses, and the start of several religious holidays worldwide. The program also covered topics such as hydraulic fracturing, the historic conqueror "Muhammadu Buhari", and the spread of diseases like Ebola in West Africa. Additionally, it highlighted recent space missions and scientific discoveries, including the use of insect-based technology to combat disease. The program concluded with a roll call for viewers to request to be mentioned on future episodes.

Liverpool striker Daniel Sturridge faces a fight to be fit for their FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa after being left out of Monday night's Barclays Premier League clash due to an injury problem. He was left out of the squad entirely for the match against Blackburn Rovers last week. Manager Brendan Rodgers has confirmed that Sturridge will be monitored ahead of the Wembley showdown on Sunday. The Reds' chances of making it into the Champions League depend on Sturridge's recovery, while Steven Gerrard could return for the semi-final against Aston Villa. With Liverpool already missing Mamadou Sakho, Adam Lallana, and Mario Balotelli through injury and illness, they remain hopeful of securing a top-four spot.

A 21-year-old man, Thomas Buckett, was severely injured when he fell 15ft through a roof while attempting to break into a tuck shop at Clayton Hall Business and Language College in Newcastle-under-Lyme. A selection of celebrities' luggage has sparked controversy due to its unusual designs, including Rihanna's gun-themed bags and Madonna's new black crocodile handbag adorned with a seemingly drug-related slogan. NBC's "World News Tonight" with David Muir has officially overtaken underfire rival "Nightly News" in the ratings war for the first time in over five and a half years. Robert Downey Jr., an Oscar-winning actor, has been accused of making a racist remark about Mexican director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu, stating that superhero movies are "cultural genocide" and implying that they kill people. This criticism came after Inarritu expressed frustration with the genre, calling it "basic and simple." A prisoner claimed that Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old man who died in police custody, was trying to injure himself in a police van, citing a leaked police report. Sir Paul McCartney married Heather Mills in 2002, but their wedding reception was marred by tension due to the presence of his first wife Linda, whom he later divorced. Ferrari driver Sebastian Vettel celebrated his fourth Formula One World Championship title win at the Malaysian Grand Prix, marking the team's first victory in nearly three decades. A 51-year-old mother and daughter, Iona Costello, and her 45-year-old daughter Emily, were found safe and well in New York City's Upper West Side neighborhood after being missing since March 30. A Nigerian Christian prayed for his life while on a rubber dinghy carrying 100 African refugees across the Mediterranean, prompting a violent confrontation between Muslim migrants and the Christian passenger. A four-month-old baby named Evan Summerfield died from meningitis, a rare and serious condition, just 12 hours after laughing for the first time. Krista Dotzenrod, a 24-year-old Chicago Cubs fan, caught a foul ball while attending a game between the Cubs and the San Diego Padres. The St Ivan Rilski Church in Bulgaria's Zapalnya village was submerged in an artificial lake 50 years ago as part of a communist-era project. The church, built in 1895, remains the only surviving remnant of the town, with some parts still standing above water. The town's residents were forced to abandon their homes and relocate to neighboring villages.
