The incident occurred during the festival, where the student was caught drinking underage. The officers involved were reportedly part of the College Station Police Department, but their identities remain unknown. The student's victory was captured on social media, with a video showing her winning the game against the officers. The incident sparked widespread amusement and praise online, with some users jokingly referring to the event as "Chilifest" and sharing memes featuring the student's victorious pose.

A 14-year-old girl named Sally Gordon-Smith went missing near Melbourne after being last seen leaving her school in Keilor East at 3pm on Friday. Police are currently searching for her and are concerned due to her age. The girl was described as Caucasian, 150cm tall, with blue eyes and brown hair, and was wearing blue jeans, black jumper, and black shoes when she disappeared. Police confirmed she was still missing early on Saturday morning.

Alan Pardew, Crystal Palace manager, denies rumors of a potential transfer to Newcastle, stating there's been no contact with the Magpies regarding goalkeeper Tim Krul. He remains committed to keeping Julian Speroni as his first-choice goalkeeper. Pardew has expressed disappointment at being linked with Krul, who currently plays for Crystal Palace. Despite this, Pardew believes the team can move forward without making a major signing.

British photographer John Daniels uses a studio setup to take pictures of adorable puppies capturing the perfect moments through various animal pairings, including kittens and ducks. His photography skills involve experimenting with different settings and techniques to create unique portraits. With years of experience, Daniels has honed his craft, allowing him to photograph even the most reluctant animals. His photographs showcase the joy and companionship between pets, highlighting the special bond between humans and animals.

A 54-year-old woman, Hilary Border, from Nottinghamshire, was sentenced to 16 months in prison after pleading guilty to stealing £20,000 from her 83-year-old mother's care home account. Her mother, who suffers from dementia, had entrusted Border with managing her finances due to her poor health. Care home staff reported that Border failed to pay the £300-a-week fee, leading to a £16,000 debt. Border claimed she took the money to alleviate personal financial difficulties, but was found to have committed fraud. She will serve 16 months in prison, suspended for two years, along with an eight-month home curfew and 150 hours of unpaid work.

David Suchet, a 68-year-old actor best known for his role as Hercule Poirot, is battling to help his grandson Todd, who has Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, an incurable genetic disease. Todd's condition requires expensive medications that are currently unavailable through the National Health Service (NHS), prompting Suchet to take action to raise awareness and advocate for better treatment options. Using the hashtag #Fight4Treatment, Suchet is urging others to join him in calling for improved administration within the NHS to provide more effective care for those affected by this rare illness. As a devout Christian, Suchet hopes to use his platform to bring attention to the plight of families like his own, where his grandson faces a challenging road ahead due to the lack of suitable treatment.

Cheteshwar Pujara has been signed by Yorkshire until the end of May after Younis Khan cancelled his contract due to visa issues. The Indian batsman will join the team as their overseas signing, replacing Younis Khan, who is currently unavailable for the upcoming tour of Bangladesh. Pujara, who scored 219 championship runs for Derbyshire last season, will link up with the Division One champions before potentially making his international debut for England. He hopes to contribute to Yorkshire's success and make his mark on the English game.

A Belgian Malinois named Layka, a hero from Afghanistan, has been adopted by US Army Staff Sergeant Julian McDonald in Ohio after losing her front leg in battle. Despite being wounded multiple times, Layka continued to fight bravely and complete her mission. McDonald adopted Layka and her son Liam, who has become close friends with the dog. Layka now resides in a loving home with McDonald and his family, where she remains a cherished companion. She continues to serve as a symbol of courage and loyalty.

A recent study questions the conventional wisdom that excessive salt consumption poses significant health risks, suggesting that the average American's daily salt intake may not carry substantial danger. Current guidelines recommend limiting salt to 2,300 milligrams per day, but some experts argue that this amount is insufficient. Research indicates that even moderate salt consumption may pose health risks, particularly for those with hypertension. The debate centers around whether the benefits of reducing salt intake outweigh the potential drawbacks. Experts disagree on the optimal level of salt consumption, with some arguing that excessive salt consumption is the primary concern.

Several DEA agents participated in alleged sex parties in Colombia from 2001 to 2001, according to a report by the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee. At least 7 DEA agents admitted to attending these parties, which were funded by Colombian prostitutes. The parties allegedly took place in Bogota, and involved DEA Special Agents who were paid by the cartel. Lawmakers grilled DEA Administrator Michele Leonhart during a recent hearing about the allegations.

A 36-year-old Louisiana sheriff's deputy, Burt Hazeltine, was shot three times while directing traffic near a school zone in Paradis, Louisiana, during a road rage incident. Paul Devillier, a 56-year-old Transportation Safety Administration employee, allegedly opened fire on Hazeltine, who was directing school buses on US 90 near Louisiana Street. Hazeltine suffered severe injuries, including a gunshot wound to the face, elbow, and eye, and is currently in stable but guarded condition at Interim LSU Hospital. Devillier was taken into custody after a brief confrontation with Hazeltine, who returned fire, and is suspected to have lost his sight due to another bullet lodged behind his eye.

A former British politician, Lord Janner, has signed a letter claiming he remains unfit to face child sex charges due to Alzheimer's disease, despite being ruled unfit to stand trial by the Crown Prosecution Service. The letter, allegedly written by Janner, claims he is "well enough" to sign it, sparking controversy among campaigners who argue he should still face trial. The letter was sent to the House of Lords authorities, prompting questions about how Janner, who was previously suspended by Labour due to child sex allegations, escaped prosecution. Janner's daughter, Rabbi Laura Janner-Klausner, has also expressed outrage, stating that her father's actions are hypocritical given his previous defense of alleged abusers.

Mehmet Selim Kiraz, a Turkish prosecutor, was killed during an armed siege at a courthouse in Istanbul, where he was being held by the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C), a far-left organization. The Turkish government blocked access to Twitter and YouTube due to the refusal of prosecutors to remove images of the siege and Kiraz's death. The images sparked grief among his family and supporters, who claim the government is trying to cover up the circumstances surrounding his death. The Turkish government had previously requested that Twitter and YouTube remove the images, but they refused, leading to the blocking of these social media platforms.

David and Victoria Beckham, a wealthy couple, have won a planning battle to install air conditioning at their £31.5 million West London mansion after facing opposition from their neighbor who claimed it would harm the historic character of the property. The couple's plans to renovate the Grade II listed mansion, which includes a luxurious interior design by Rose Uniacke, were approved by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Council despite concerns about noise, vibration, and pollution. The plans were seen as a prudent and sensible move to enhance the property's value over time. The Beckhams' new home, located in Holland Park, is expected to be worth up to £42 million once complete.

California Governor Jerry Brown ordered a 25% overall cutback in water use across the state due to ongoing drought conditions. This includes cities and towns, as well as residential areas, aiming to conserve water resources. The cutback affects nearly 40 million residents, with wells in some areas drying up due to low groundwater levels. The goal is to reduce water usage by 1/4 of the 2013 level, with exemptions for agriculture, cemeteries, and businesses.

Furious 7, directed by James Wan, is set to open in theaters nationwide on April 27th, marking a historic opening weekend for the film. With a projected domestic opening of $115 million or more, Furious 7 surpasses the previous record held by Captain America: The Winter Soldier, which opened to $95 million in April 2014. The film features Vin Diesel reprising his role as Dominic Toretto alongside new additions like Jason Statham's Deckard Shaw. Furious 7 marks a significant milestone in Universal's history, as it opens globally on 10,500 screens across 63 territories, including a record-breaking 4,003 in the US.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas struggled in his second half of the season after a strong start, captaining Spain in a 2-0 loss to Holland. His form has dipped significantly, with only 4/10 received by one Spanish newspaper, despite being expected to lead the Barclays Premier League title chase. Fabregas' recent performances have raised concerns about his durability, particularly considering the pressure of the final stretch of the season. With Chelsea facing a tough schedule ahead, Fabregas' goal-scoring record may be crucial in securing the Premier League title. If he can find form again, Chelsea could potentially wrap up the title within weeks.

A group of 750 plaintiffs, including Marta Orellana and Marta Ruiz, are suing Johns Hopkins University over a medical experiment where the US government deliberately infected individuals with syphilis in Guatemala from 1945 to 1956. The experiment involved injecting syphilis into unwitting participants, including children, soldiers, and mentally ill individuals, resulting in severe physical and emotional trauma. The victims suffered from various disabilities, including blindness, deafness, and brain damage, and some were forced to pass the disease on to their children. The US government initially denied involvement in the study, but later acknowledged it in 2010, leading to a $1 billion lawsuit.

Nelly, a 40-year-old hip-hop artist, was arrested in Tennessee on drug charges after a state trooper stopped his private bus carrying him and others on Interstate 40. The bus was found to have marijuana, methamphetamine, and other drug paraphernalia, and multiple handguns were discovered. Nelly was charged with felony possession of drugs, simple possession of marijuana, and possession of drug paraphernalia. A state trooper noticed the odor of marijuana while inspecting the bus, leading to its stop.

A Japanese woman gave her cheating boyfriend an Apple collection a devastating revenge by washing his expensive gadgets in a bathtub, including his iMac, iPhone, iPad, and accessories. The woman scorned took great care to ensure the damage was total, tweeting pictures of the soaked devices to humiliate him. Many people praised the woman's bold move, calling it "the best revenge" and "the best way to teach someone a lesson." Others commended the woman for standing up for herself and showing no remorse for her actions.

Bayern Munich won 1-0 against Borussia Dortmund in their Bundesliga match, with Robert Lewandowski scoring the winning goal. Jurgen Klopp expressed satisfaction with the result, saying Bayern deserved to win despite struggling to create chances throughout the game. Dortmund captain Mats Hummels disagreed, stating that the visitors merited more goals due to creating several chances. Lewandowski's goal was celebrated by Bayern fans, while Klopp praised his team's performance, calling them "charismatic".

President Barack Obama visited Jamaica on Thursday, becoming the first American president to do so since President Ronald Reagan in 1982. He met with Jamaican Prime Minister Portia Simpson Miller and expressed his love for the country, stating "you're well-loved" in Jamaica. Obama also met with Cuban President Raul Castro, who attended a dinner with him on Friday, marking the first time the two leaders have met since the thawing of relations in December. Meanwhile, US Secretary of State John Kerry met with Cuban Foreign Minister Bruno Rodriguez in Panama City, discussing ways to improve relations between the two nations.

Pope Francis delivered a powerful message during his "Urbi et Orbi" address, reminding the world of the importance of ending violence and promoting peace. He specifically addressed the ongoing conflicts in Iraq, Syria, Libya, Yemen, Nigeria, and South Sudan, calling for an end to bloodshed and urging humanitarian aid to those affected. The Pope also expressed hope for a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and encouraged the international community to work towards healing in Ukraine. In addition, he emphasized the need for peace and freedom from economic exploitation, particularly against marginalized communities.

Linda Farrow eyewear's Spring Summer 15 campaign features Irina Shayk posing in a steamy video with model Jarrod Scott, showcasing their romantic getaway to LA. The campaign, shot by Mariano Vivanco, highlights Irina's stunning figure in various plunging metallic swimsuits paired with retro-inspired sunglasses. Irina's style is complemented by Topshop gold round frame sunglasses, which add a touch of glamour to her overall look. The campaign aims to deliver an extended palette of colors, including metallic and liquid gold shades.

Polish Prince Janek Zylinski has challenged Nigel Farage, the leader of the UKIP, to a sword fight over his criticism of immigration. Zylinski, a descendant of a Polish war hero who fought against Nazi forces in 1939, claims he has "had enough" of Farage's comments about Polish people being blamed for traffic jams. Zylinski, who lives in Ealing, West London, posted the challenge online, saying it's time for a duel between the two men. The challenge includes a reference to the Polish war hero who helped save 6,000 Jews during World War II.

Barcelona defender Dani Alves has been offered a two-year deal by Manchester United, according to reports, which could keep him at the club until June 30. This development has sparked hope among fans that Alves might consider staying at the Nou Camp, despite rumors suggesting he's being courted by other top clubs like Manchester City and Paris Saint-Germain. Alves' camp claims the offer is a "one-year deal" with an option for a second year, while Barcelona's president Joan Laporta says the club is willing to keep Alves on board. However, Alves' wife Dinorah Santa Ana has expressed doubts about the offer, stating she hopes her husband stays with Barcelona.

A 33-year-old hairdresser, Kate Temple, was jailed for 20 months after admitting to inflicting grievous bodily harm on a 29-year-old woman, Shelley Williams, at a charity event. Williams claimed that Temple had an affair with her partner, but prosecutors argued that she had simply gotten the wrong end of the stick. Temple attacked Williams while they were getting ready to leave a marquee at a cricket match, biting off a chunk of Williams' ear. Williams suffered serious injuries and underwent reconstructive surgery, and was forced to cancel plans with her family and colleagues due to the trauma. Temple was sentenced to 20 months in prison for her role in the attack.

Jenson Button believes McLaren has improved significantly since their poor start to the season in Australia, making progress in the form of better pace and performance. In contrast, McLaren's rival teams such as Red Bull, Sauber, and Lotus showed faster times. Button hopes to continue improving and eventually catch up with these top teams. He also appreciates the cooler weather forecasted for the upcoming Shanghai Grand Prix, which may help generate higher tire temperatures. With Honda's new power unit, McLaren is looking to push themselves against the likes of Red Bull and Sauber.

A 33-year-old woman, Claudia Martins, was convicted of murdering her newborn baby girl by suffocating her with toilet paper and hiding the body in a suitcase. Martins gave birth alone to the child in her sister's flat in Bristol, keeping the pregnancy a secret from her family and others. After giving birth, Martins was found dead in the bathroom with a wad of toilet paper in her mouth, and a post-mortem revealed that the baby was stillborn. Martins claimed she did not kill the baby, stating she did not put anything in her throat, and was subsequently convicted of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility due to her low IQ.

AP McCoy, riding for Paul Nicholls, will compete in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. He is paired with Mr Mole, a Grade One contender trained by the same trainer. The event marks a significant milestone for McCoy, who announced his retirement from riding earlier this year. Mr Mole will be ridden by Nico de Boinville in the absence of injured rider Barry Geraghty. This will be McCoy's last ride before he hangs up his jockey's helmet.

A woman in her 20s was rescued from the River Cam in Cambridge after falling from a punt and struggling to stay afloat. She was found by two friends who leapt in to save her and were able to pull her to safety. The incident occurred after the punt hit another boat, causing the woman to fall underwater several times. Temperatures in Cambridge reached an average of 22°C, warmer than usual, and the warm weather continued throughout the day.

West Indies' Marlon Samuels has shown remarkable dedication and perseverance in taking on the demands of Test cricket, particularly in the second Test against England. As a former West Indies player himself, Samuels understands the value of playing long, grueling matches that require discipline and mental toughness. His achievement of reaching 103 runs in the second Test is a testament to his ability to perform under pressure. With a new West Indies coach, Phil Simmons, aiming to instill a sense of discipline and pride in the team, Samuels' performance will likely serve as a model for others. The author notes that Test cricket offers a unique experience that cannot be replicated in shorter formats like Twenty20.

A police officer named Michael Slager shot and killed a 50-year-old man named Walter Scott while responding to a call about a broken brake light. Slager fired multiple shots at Scott, who was handcuffed and lying on the ground, and then used a Taser on him. An internal investigation found that Slager's fellow officers, including one who searched Scott's body, failed to provide adequate medical care, despite being present at the scene. The incident sparked widespread outrage and calls for greater accountability within the police department.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model, denied reports that she attempted to take her own life after collapsing in a luxury apartment in Milan. Italian media reported that she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure but later stated that she was actually injured in a domestic accident. Her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, suggested that she had tried to take her own life, but Moric disputed this claim. Moric posted several photographs on her Instagram account showing her injuries, stating that she was recovering at home and had no intention of ending her life.

Juventus secured a 0-0 draw against Monaco in their Champions League quarter-final match, thanks largely to the efforts of Patrice Evra, who prevented Yannick Ferreira Carrasco from scoring. The French defender had a nervy performance, allowing Monaco to dominate possession, while also preventing Geoffrey Kondogbia from delivering a cross at the Stade Louis II. Despite this, Evra believes that Juventus' approach can serve as an example to other top-tier clubs, such as PSG, which lost to Barcelona in the previous round. Paul Pogba will miss the Champions League semi-finals due to injury, prompting Evra to urge him to avoid rushing his recovery.

A gorilla at Omaha's Henry Doorley Zoo threw a pane of glass at a child during a family outing, causing significant damage. The incident occurred when the gorilla, weighing around 485lb, became frustrated and attacked the glass after being told not to beat itself. The gorilla then ran towards the glass, striking it with incredible force, causing it to crack. The family fled in terror, while the zookeepers tried to intervene but ultimately retreated from the scene.

John Suchet, a British actor, lost his wife Bonnie in April 2015 after a decade-long battle with dementia. Bonnie suffered from the illness for over seven years before passing away peacefully at the age of 73. As a devoted husband and father, Suchet dedicated himself to caring for Bonnie, eventually moving her to a residential home where she received better care. Despite struggling with feelings of guilt and sadness, Suchet remained committed to supporting those affected by dementia through his charity work.

Shelby Offrink, a 30-year-old mother of two young children, met Ben in college and later married him after battling Hodgkin's lymphoma. When Shelby was diagnosed with a rare type of brain cancer called an intramedullary glioblastoma, she underwent surgery and chemotherapy, but unfortunately, the cancer recurred and spread to her spine. Despite facing numerous challenges, including losing mobility due to paralysis, Shelby remains determined to fight the disease and eventually finds new treatments, including a potential bone marrow transplant. Her husband, Ben, continues to support her efforts, along with their two daughters, Maeve and Hazel, and their older brother, Jay, who helps manage their daily needs.

Real Madrid coach Carlo Ancelotti faces a difficult decision when selecting his starting lineup due to the availability of several key players, including James Rodriguez, who has been injured since November. The team's attack is bolstered by Gareth Bale, Karim Benzema, and Cristiano Ronaldo, but Ancelotti must decide whether to include either Rodriguez or Isco in the starting lineup. Meanwhile, Paris Saint-Germain's 3-2 win over Marseille highlights the improving quality of Ligue 1, which currently sits atop the table with 62 points. Real Madrid's attacking trio of Isco, Toni Kroos, and Luka Modric remains a strong option, but Ancelotti may need to make a tough choice given their injury status.

Manny Pacquiao and Floyd Mayweather will face off in the highly anticipated "Fight of the Century" at the MGM Grand on May 2. Mayweather met fellow boxer Manny Pacquiao in a pre-fight photo shoot with Motown legend Gladys Knight, who posted a picture with the boxer on social media. The two fighters have been preparing for their upcoming bout, which promises to be one of the biggest events in boxing history. Mayweather has secured a reported £120 million from the fight, while Pacquiao is also set to receive a significant amount.

A leadership coaching firm called ExtendedMind has hired Ed Miliband to help him improve his public speaking skills through "neuroscience" and "business psychology". The firm claims to provide services such as building "leadership skills", helping politicians to become more authentic, and negotiating with allies. The firm's methods involve teaching politicians how to look "authentic" and build relationships, but critics say this approach may be superficial. The firm's CEO, David Axelrod, has worked with Barack Obama, while Miliband has hired him despite reportedly receiving criticism over the cost.

A 32-year-old dispatcher for US Limousine, Geralyn Ganci, sued her former employer Raymond Townsend, a limousine company manager, for sexual harassment and refusing to engage in consensual sex. Ganci alleged that Townsend made explicit and unwanted advances towards her, including sending her explicit texts and asking her to meet him outside of work. After being fired, Ganci received a settlement of over $700,000 from the company and $550,000 in damages from Townsend. In 2010, a federal jury found Townsend liable for creating a hostile work environment due to his behavior, but he was not held personally responsible for the damages.

Thiago made his return to action for Bayern Munich in a 1-0 win over Borussia Dortmund on Saturday. He came off the bench to replace Philipp Lahm and scored no goals. This marked his first appearance in over a year. Thiago expressed gratitude towards the fans who supported him during his recovery period. His emotional performance was seen by many as a reminder of the importance of football in his life.

David Cameron, the former UK Prime Minister, accused the BBC of peddling misinformation when he claimed his favorite sport was foxhunting. During an appearance on the Andrew Marr Show, he denied saying foxhunting was his favorite sport, despite earlier admitting to making a mistake. The BBC presenter Andrew Marr had questioned whether Cameron's favorite sport was indeed foxhunting, prompting Cameron to climb onto a wooden pallet to address the audience. Cameron later apologized for the mistake, stating that he had initially believed foxhunting was his preferred sport due to its connection to country sports.

Gwyneth Paltrow, actress and lifestyle guru, participated in the #FoodBankNYCChallenge, where she spent $29 on leafy greens, dried beans, and rice for a week, showcasing the challenges faced by people living on food stamps. This effort aims to raise awareness about the struggles of those who rely on food stamps due to Congressional cuts. The challenge encourages individuals to live on a limited food budget, with some participants using as little as $1.38 per meal. The initiative was prompted by recent cuts to food stamps, which have affected many families.

Manchester United's Megastore, featuring mascot Fred the Red, is facing uncertainty due to a potential expiration of its world-record £750m kit deal with Nike. Staff, including Fred, are concerned about their future employment status, citing low wages and lack of job security. The club's official mascot, Fred, has been with the team since 1994 and is among those sweating over the situation. As the Megastore nears closure, some staff claim they are being used as scapegoats by Nike, while others fear losing their jobs if the deal ends.

Liverpool edged past Blackburn Rovers 1-0 in the FA Cup sixth-round replay, thanks to a crucial goal from Philippe Coutinho. The Brazilian midfielder broke the deadlock after 161 minutes, scoring in a thrilling comeback win. Blackburn struggled to create clear-cut chances throughout the game, while Liverpool's defense held firm until Coutinho sealed the victory. Raheem Sterling was quiet in attack, but Liverpool's midfield duo of Coutinho and Steven Gerrard controlled the tempo of the game. The Reds ultimately won 1-0, securing their place in the 24th FA Cup semi-final.

A heartwarming video shows six blindfolded children trying to identify their mothers by touch and scent. The video, titled "The Unique Connection," aims to explore the special bond between mothers and children. The children are guided by their mothers' voices, but not visual cues, allowing them to recognize each other. The video celebrates Mother's Day 2015 and has gained significant attention online, with over 2.8 million views.

Ian Watson, a 38-year-old Salford assistant coach, is set to return to the club as a player-coach after stepping up his training ahead of their upcoming match against Castleford. This move comes after the team suffered a significant loss due to injuries, leaving them without several key players. As part of the coaching staff, Watson will take on a new role, marking a rare instance where a player returns to the club as a coach rather than a player. With his experience and leadership skills, Watson could potentially help guide the team back into action. His decision to step away from playing adds another layer of depth to the coaching staff.

Jordan Spieth sank a remarkable six birdies in his first round at the 79th Masters, taking the lead with a three-shot advantage over Justin Rose and Ernie Els. Spieth's incredible performance included a birdie on the 18th hole, where he successfully sunk a 25-foot putt to maintain his lead. Younger competitors like Rory McIlroy and Phil Mickelson also performed well, with McIlroy recording an impressive five-under-par 67. Meanwhile, veteran golfer Ernie Els showed signs of returning to form, posting an impressive five-under-par 67.

England's captain Alastair Cook must focus on the upcoming Test series against the West Indies despite distractions such as the departure of key player Kevin Pietersen and the impending arrival of new director of cricket Colin Graves. Cook has worked hard to regain form after a disappointing World Cup campaign and is determined to prove himself in the series. The three-match series is considered crucial for Cook's career, and he must avoid distractions to ensure he delivers. With a strong squad and a new coaching staff, England is confident of taking on the West Indies, who are expected to be a formidable opponent. The series promises to be a high-stakes test of Cook's leadership skills and ability to perform under pressure.

A US Navy ship, the USS Oklahoma, sank in the bombing of Pearl Harbor in 1941, resulting in the deaths of nearly 400 sailors and Marines. The ship was attacked by Japanese forces and capsized, trapping many inside. Nearly 400 bodies remain unidentified, with only 35 identified in the years following the incident. A new policy allows the Pentagon to exhume the remains of unknown individuals, with the goal of identifying at least 60% of the group using DNA samples, medical records, and other evidence.

A YouTube video titled "I Disguised Myself as Homeless Man to See What Happens If I Offer People Money" features Yousef Saleh Erakat, a popular YouTube personality, who disguises himself as a homeless man to test whether people would respond positively to receiving money from strangers. In the video, Erakat attempts to flip the script by offering people money instead of receiving it, with mixed reactions ranging from anger to kindness. Two men in suits initially refuse Erakat's offers, while others, such as a woman who offers him money for breakfast, show generosity and humility. The video raises questions about the value of material possessions and the importance of selflessness.

A 18-year-old college student, Anjelica Hadsell, disappeared while on spring break in Norfolk, Virginia, leaving her family worried and seeking answers. Her mother, Katherine Hadsell, has accused police of not doing enough to find her daughter, with her stepfather, Wesley Hadsell, taking matters into his own hands by investigating the disappearance. Wesley, a convicted felon with a history of domestic violence, was arrested for breaking into a home where Anjelica was last seen, and police have found evidence of his involvement in the case. The investigation is ongoing, with police searching a pond near the Hadsell residence and questioning Wesley, who has a history of violent behavior.

A team of Australian researchers has developed a drone called Joggobot, which can fly alongside joggers to provide a running companion. The drone uses a camera to track the jogger's speed and direction, allowing it to maintain a consistent pace. Researchers tested the drone with 13 joggers over two hours, finding that most participants enjoyed the experience and felt motivated to continue running. The drone's ability to lock onto a pattern on the jogger's shirt allowed it to provide a sense of peer pressure, similar to running with a human companion.

Matthew Bird, a 28-year-old truck driver from Ashburton, New Zealand, quit his well-paying job as an agricultural adviser to become a mechanic due to rising child support payments. His monthly payment increased from $1,900 to $554, making him one of several individuals affected by the change. The increase is attributed to the revised child support formula, which now calculates payments based on a lower income threshold. This change affects approximately 70,000 families across New Zealand, according to Inland Revenue.

British trader Navinder Singh Sarao, 36, has been accused of causing the 2010 "flash crash" by making illicit trades worth £26 million over five years. Authorities suspect he used special computer software to manipulate the market on Wall Street, despite being warned about his activities in 2009. The incident caused significant losses in the US stock market, with the Dow Jones plummeting 600 points between 2.42pm and 2.47pm on May 6, 2010. US authorities eventually charged Sarao with criminal charges alongside the Department of Justice, citing evidence gathered through a whistleblower tip-off.

Lisa Webb, a Canadian expat mom, initially worried about her three-year-old daughter eating vegetables in France due to the country's emphasis on a traditional gastronomic meal. However, after spending a week in the French state school, she discovered that the children were eating a variety of dishes, including meat, fruits, and desserts, which surprised her. As a substitute teacher, Lisa found herself enjoying the French meal culture and learning about the country's unique approach to dining. Her experience changed her perspective on food and parenting, making her appreciate the simplicity and joy of sharing meals with her children.

A survey found that 64% of adults who shop with friends tend to spend more money than they would if they shopped alone, citing factors such as showing off and succumbing to peer pressure. Many participants reported feeling guilty after making purchases with friends, but prioritizing their own financial goals helped alleviate these feelings. According to the survey, 85% of participants plan to stick to their budgets when shopping, despite admitting to overspending on various items like food, clothing, and entertainment. The results suggest that friends can play a role in encouraging over-spending, particularly when it comes to discretionary expenses like food and shoes.

Phillip Schofield, 53, appeared on ITV's This Morning to discuss his fiancée Ellie Grant, 22, who has Tourette's syndrome. Ellie, a community support worker, revealed that she developed the condition at age 21 and initially feared finding a partner who would tolerate her outbursts. However, her fiancé Jordan, who is deaf, helped her cope with her symptoms, switching off his hearing aid during their interactions. The couple appeared on the show to discuss their unusual relationship and how they've learned to adapt together.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old US citizen and al Qaeda operative, was killed in a US government counterterrorism operation in January. He was involved in various terrorist activities, including planning attacks in the UK, Australia, and Afghanistan, and was known for his anti-American rhetoric. Gadahn was killed alongside two other US citizens, Ahmed Farouq and Warren Weinstein, in a separate operation. This marked the end of his involvement with al Qaeda, which had previously considered him one of its top leaders.

Jenson Button, a Formula One driver, completed the London Marathon in 2 hours, 52 minutes, 30 seconds, beating his personal best time. He ran for charity, supporting Cancer Research. Button expressed his delight at finishing ahead of fellow athlete James Cracknell, who finished third. Button described the event as "amazing" and praised its collective spirit. He credited the crowd's support for making the experience emotionally rewarding.
